courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Introduction to Social Work and Social Welfare

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This is an introductory course on the concept and meaning of social work and social welfare. It aims to help students understand the role of social welfare in society and the role of social work as a helping profession in social welfare. Course content includes appraising the mission, scope, and functions of social welfare and social work, examining different welfare approaches, and discussing factors giving rise to unmet needs. The relationship between social welfare and other social institutions, and the major types of social welfare services in Hong Kong will also be introduced. Special attention will be given to addressing the plights of vulnerable populations and promoting social justice, and to equip students with foundation knowledge and essential values for the profession of social work.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What is social work?

2. What is social welfare?

3. Relationship between social work and social welfare

4. The roles of social welfare and social work in the changing society

5. Social welfare and social work in Hong Kong

6. Social welfare and social work practice in selected countries

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Self-development in Changing Society

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: Hong Kong and the global society are undergoing rapid social change, such as the rising number of nuclear families, post-divorce families and single-parent families; the dwindling of upward mobility opportunities for the young generation; and the increasingly volatile economic outlook due to globalization. In this multi-dimensional society of chaos and uncertainty, the younger generation is prone to confusion and a lack of direction. This course aims to help students who have just reached adulthood to understand personal growth, to develop self-acceptance, to reflect upon their self-identity and to recognize the impact of the rapid changing society on an individual. It is hoped that the course can assist students to develop direction and values in facing various life tasks, prepare them for choices in life path and equip them with a proactive manner in future study / career.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOWK1150, SOWK2110, UGED1600, UGED2591, GESC2117 or PSYC1030.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After studying this course, students will be able to:

1) Acquire basic knowledge on human nature and self development

2) Understand the reciprocal influence between self and environment

3) Identify factors and social forces affecting self development in different aspects

4) Understand the possibilities and challenges in the course of self-development

5) Examine their current values and attitudes related to various life tasks

6) Reflect on their goals and purposes in living in the changing society
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Changing self and changing society

- Who are you? Where are you?

- Person-in-environment

2. Understand yourself in the changing society :

- Psychosocial/developmental perspective

- Humanistic perspective

- Cognitive perspective

- Psychoanalytic perspective

- Behaviorist perspectives

- Ecological System Theory

- Social Changes and Social Responsibility

3. Developing yourself in context

- Death, dying and Bereavement

- Values and Meaning in life

- University life & career

- Gender Role and Sexuality

- Love Relationship

4. Review and Conclusion: Enhancing Self-development
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussion with students

2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaires

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: From Understanding to Empowering the Socially Disadvantaged
courses.description: The number of socially disadvantaged people, particularly individuals with disabilities, aged, newly arrived immigrants, ethnic minorities and homeless people, has been increasing rapidly. There are different attitudes towards these socially disadvantaged groups: discrimination, avoidance, sympathy, acceptance and understanding. The course reviews how these attitudes were constructed socially and spread in our society. The course aims to promote students’ reflection and to enhance their understanding on the causes and livelihood of the socially disadvantaged. Experiential learning opportunity such as community visits, community education projects with involvement of the disadvantaged groups in social change are means to be employed to facilitate students’ learning and to achieve the goal of empowerment. Related community resources and methods to improve the well-being of the disadvantaged group will also be discussed. This course is inter-disciplinary in focus, emphasizing social, cultural, historical, and geographical aspects of exclusion and marginalization. Theories of social exclusion, social justice, social construction etc. will be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOWK2190 or UGEC2014.
courses.course_syllabus:
The core content of this course is as follows:

- Understanding the situations of the socially disadvantaged groups

- Dominant discourses and social construction of social vulnerability and disadvantaged

- Theories of social stratification, social exclusion, marginalisation, social construction, social justice and empowerment

- Evolving societal attitudes toward socially disadvantaged in service delivery, legislation and policy

- Enhancing social and individual well-being of the socially disadvantaged groups

- Strategies to achieve individual and social empowerment of the socially disadvantaged groups

- Reviewing the strengths and limitations of different policy initiatives and social programs in helping the socially disadvantaged groups

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Living with Grief: Understanding Death, Dying and Bereavement
courses.description:
(UGED1602 is double-coded with SOWK1130.)

Death is not special. It happens every day and everywhere. It is also an inevitable part of life. Yet, death is very important for us especially when we are confronted by the death and dying of our loved ones. Surprisingly, we have done little to prepare ourselves to get familiar with the topic of bereavement. Very often we learn it only from the most painful and heartbreaking moments in life—after the death of loved ones. While bereavement may induce us different grief reactions, and adjustment difficulties, it also provides an opportunity for us to experience personal growth, reflect on our values and search for the meaning in life.

As a result, this course aims to prepare students to face death, dying and bereavement that they may encounter in their life. In particular, they are facilitated to respond to a unique question, “How can I live with the grief?” This question can only be answered by the students themselves who will have an opportunity to understand more about death, dying and bereavement, as well as reflecting on their life and living through this course.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic knowledge on death and dying:

a. concepts of good death,

b. attitudes towards death, e.g. death anxiety, death acceptance

c. the dying process,

d. adjustment to anticipatory grief

2. Basic knowledge on bereavement,

a. grief reactions

b. grief processes and theories, e.g. Dual Process Model

c. specific types of bereavement, e.g. suicidal bereavement, men’s grief, elderly grief, children’s grief, etc.

d. adjustment bereavement, and living with grief

3. Values, life priorities and meaning in life

a. Existential perspective on life, death and bereavement

b. Search for meaning in life following bereavement (e.g. Vitkor Frankl’s logotherapeutic perspective)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Choices in Life: An Invitation to Self-Development
courses.description:
(UGED1600 is double-coded with SOWK1150.)

This course adopts a humanistic approach to personal growth. It aims at facilitating students to achieve better self-understanding and self-confidence, expand options in life and develop greater self-acceptance. Through classroom instruction and small group experiential learning, students will be guided to review their personal growth and development, to examine issues and choices in significant aspects of their lives, and to reflect on their values and attitudes. Major topics covered include human development, family and relationships, love and sexuality, health and wellness, society and social responsibility, study and career, and death and loss.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED2591, UGED1600, GESC2117, PSYC1030 or SOWK1113.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction : Making life choices & Self-reflections

1. 1. Risk in an age of uncertainty

1. 2. Opportunity amidst danger

1. 3. Person-in-situation : making choices in the multi-level context of life

1. 4. Ways to make self-reflections

2. Different views of human being

2. 1. The Psychoanalytic view

2. 2. The Behaviourist view

2. 3. The Existential-humanistic view

3. The life course – A developmental perspective on human growth

3. 1. Stages of development in the life course

3. 2. Developmental crisis and developmental tasks

3. 3. The construction of life script

4. Dealing with self-defeating injunctions in making life choices

4. 1. Concepts of the ABC Model & Self-defeating irrational beliefs

4. 2. How do irrational beliefs affect our emotion and behaviour

4. 3. Changing your self-defeating thinking pattern to a self-constructive one

5. Making choices in significant life issues regarding

5. 1. Family

5. 2. Sex role and sexuality

5. 3. Love and courtship

5. 4. Career & study

5. 5. Society and social responsibility

5. 6. Death and loss

5. 7. Meaning and values

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Movies, Life and Social Work
courses.description:
(UGED1651 is double-coded with SOWK1160.)

This course is designed to examine human life issues through movie watching. A social work perspective and a humanistic outlook of life will be adopted to view human lives at individual, family and society levels. Students are expected to develop an awareness and a sense of concern for people and the society. Movies related to social work values, such as people's capacity for change, respect for human worth and dignity, and social justice will be reviewed and discussed. Social issues, such as discrimination, mental illness and issue of oppression will also be covered.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Essence of social work practice; what can be offered by movies (entertainment, knowing about the world around, thought-inspiration) – how movies reflect on human lives and social conditions.

2. Connecting to humanity in movies: The “Humanistic” view of human being –

* a genuine concern for people’s lives
* a high respect for human value
* a loving heart for touching with human sufferings and people’s struggles, etc.

3. The “Psychoanalytic” view of human being -

* structure of personality, how it differs from the humanistic view
* conscious & unconscious in relating to human behaviours
* service gaps in working with people having mental health problems

4. Today’s Youngsters: At the Crossroad – a) “Behavioural” view of human being; and b) ‘Cognitive-behavioural” view

* the importance of environment in shaping behaviours of human
* familial, social and personal issues faced by our young generations
* youth service in Hong Kong

5. Love Relationships

* Essence of Love Affairs/Romantic Relationships
* Common issues encountered by social workers, e.g. Extra-marital affairs

6. Fight for justice

* what is justice and injustice
* standing for justice
* social advocacy for justice

7. Poverty

* a big gap between the rich & the poor
* social measures to reduce poverty

8. Lonely elderly?

* needs of elderly
* to concern for the well-being of our elderly
* elderly service in Hong Kong

9. Treasure the Family

* common issues in family
* dealing with communication barriers

10. Sexual discrimination in society

* homosexuality as a social issue
* our attitudes towards sexual orientation

11. Getting Free from Stress & Anxiety/Take good care of our mental health

* sources of stress
* effects of stress
* coping well with stress

12. Life is what we make of it

* how we perceive life and cope with human adversity
* people can enjoy life when they encounter difficulties and hardships

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Student-Orientated Teaching I
courses.description:
This is a small group, semi-structured teaching course which is related to the students' coursework learning, but not formally tied to any particular course. It aims to help students to examine the meaning of helping and to reflect on their views on social work as a helping profession. Students are encouraged to review their own values, attitudes and commitments as well as related issues in pursuing a career in the human services.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students are expected to:

1. Achieve understanding of the self and the family in relation to the society.
2. Apprehend the significance of self-understanding to helping and social work learning.
3. Enhance the capacity in social work learning via self-reflections, self-love and self-awareness.
4. Reflect the values and attitudes for pursuing a career in social work.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding about myself, family and the influence of family on me
2. What is the meaning of help and helping attitude of a social worker
3. Relationship between the person and the environment in the changing contexts
4. Review on life goals, values and aptitudes in pursuing a career in social work
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.description: This course aims to enable students to develop a basic understanding of social work. It will examine the nature and scope of social work practice and look into the philosophical base, value system and practice principles of the social work profession. Discussion will focus on emerging trends of social work, ethical dilemma in social work practice, as well as the application of social work values and principles in practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Nature of Social Work
2. Philosophical Base and Core Values of Social Work
3. Ethical Issues and Decision-Making in Social Work Practice
4. Social Work Relationship
5. On Becoming a Social Worker
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Interprofessional Learning for Social Work in Health Care
courses.description: This course enables students to explore, in an interprofessional context, the social issues in the health care and understand the roles and functions of social work in health care system. A primary objective is to provide students with innovative, cross-disciplinary, team-based learning experience which involves medicine, nursing, pharmacy, public health and other health profession to develop knowledge, skills and attitudes related to competence in interprofessional collaboration, foster interprofessional teamwork in health care, and prepare them for careers across healthcare-relevant practice settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. fundamental concept of interprofessional collaboration
2. health care policy and social issues related to health care
3. common health care problems during aging
4. health care promotion, disease treatment and prevention
5. health care education to service users in laymen language
6. roles and functions of different healthcare service providers
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation questionnaire, followed by discussion with students.
2. Term-end standardized course evaluation questionnaires.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Service-learning Online Course
courses.description: This online course aims to provide students with an overview of Service-Learning (S-L), including its definition, its relevant concepts and theories, and its implications for the good of society and enhancement of personal development. Through different online materials and interactive exercises, students can learn how to assess the needs of different communities, define objectives, design service projects creatively, implement the projects to meet these needs, and develop methods to evaluate the outcomes. Students will be encouraged to reflect on how the knowledge and skills that they have acquired in their own disciplines may facilitate the development of S-L projects. It is designed in the form of self-paced e-Learning modules which can be taken as a standalone prerequisite to students’ self-initiated service projects.
courses.course_attributes:
Service Learning Course
Virtual Teaching & Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Module 1: Introduction to S-L**

* The Concept of S-L vs Other Types of Service
* Types of S-L: Direct and indirect services
* Experiential Learning
+ Authentic Learning in Progressive Schools
+ S-L and Experiential Learning: Kolb's Experiential Learning Model
* Code of Ethics of S-L

* *Module 2: An overview on Design Thinking**

* Principles of Design Thinking
* 5 stages of Design Thinking
* Divergence, Convergence, and Iteration in Design Thinking Stages
* Applying Design Thinking to S-L

* *Module 3: Empathize – Data Collection**

* Defining Community
* Data Collection methods
* Communication Skills
+ Engagement and interview skills
+ Coping with challenges in Interviews

* *Module 4: Define: Assessment of Needs**

* What is Needs Assessment?
+ Different levels of “Needs”?
+ The “N3C” model
+ Problem Translation
* A Point of View (P.O.V.) statement as objectives of service projects

* *Module 5: Ideate: Creating Innovative Solutions**

* SCAMPER, a Technique for Brainstorming
* Principles to Brainstorming & Prioritize Project Ideas

* *Module 6 - Prototype & Test: Program Planning and Evaluation**

* Prototype and Testing
+ Importance of Experimenting
+ Types of Prototyping
+ Project Proposal - 6W2H
* Improving Design through Evaluation
* Deepen Learning in Service-Learning - Reflection
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term Course Questionnaire
2. Term-end Standardized Course Evaluation Questionnaire (CTE)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Human Behaviour and the Social Environment
courses.description: This course aims to enable students to understand the basic concepts, theories, and problems in human growth and behaviour as related to social work practice. Emphasis is given to the study of human growth and behaviour across the life span within different socio-cultural contexts, including family, group, organization and community settings. Attention will be paid to physical, psychological and socio-cultural aspects of growth and the reciprocal interactions between individuals, families, groups, and the environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOWK1113 and PSYC2540.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Study of human development
2. Human nature and theories
3. Prenatal development, birth, physical and cognitive development during the first three years
4. Psychosocial development during the first three years
5. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in early childhood
6. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in middle childhood
7. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in adolescence
8. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in young adulthood
9. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in middle adulthood
10. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in late adulthood
11. The end of life: death, dying and bereavement
12. Social work practice: understanding human behaviors in the social environment
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Mental Disorders
courses.description: This course aims to enable students to understand the various forms, classification, assessment, causes and management of mental disorders including mental illness and mental deficiency. Emphasis will also be put on the psychosocial impacts of mental disorders on individuals and families; and the roles of social worker in psychiatric rehabilitation and mental health services.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PSYC3700.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course Introduction: Concepts of mental health and mental disorders & Objectives of mental health practice in social work
2. Psychopathology with existential perspective
3. Recovery model and its application
4. Diagnosis and Mental Health Assessment
5. Case assessment and formulation
6. Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
7. Mood Disorder: Depressive Disorders
8. Mood Disorder: Bipolar and related Disorders
9. Mood Disorder: Anxiety and Panic Disorders
10. Mood Disorder: Obsessive-Compulsive and Hoarding Disorders
11. Mood Disorder: Personality Disorders
12. Mental Disorders for Childhood and Elderly
13. Medicine, other modes of treatment and interprofessional communication
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Economic Insecurity and Social Security in Global Contexts
courses.description:
(UGEC2631 is double-coded with SOWK2160.)

This course aims at analyzing economic insecurity from a global perspective and introducing social security as a societal measure to combat economic insecurity. Specifically, this course will examine the sources of economic insecurity of the individual and the relationship between globalization and economic insecurity. It will also discuss the philosophy, development, characteristics and functions of different types of social security measures in different countries and analyze current debates on the future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Insecurity and economic insecurity**
1. Meaning and types of insecurity in the globalised world
2. Economic insecurity – definition, sources and impact
3. Economic and financial globalization and economic insecurity

* *Understanding global poverty**

1. Concepts and definitions

2. Theories of poverty causation

3. Measuring poverty, poverty incidence and trends

4. Strategies to combat poverty and economic insecurity

5. Global overview of economic insecurity and poverty

6. Global goals, frameworks and strategies in eradicating poverty and economic insecurity

* *Social security: a strategy to combat poverty and economic insecurity**

1. Concept, definitions, objectives and scope

2. Historical trends in social security development

3. Types and branches of social security provisions and their underpinning values and principles

4. Structural components of social security provisions

5. Welfare ideologies and social security systems

6. Global overview of social security practices

7. Development and provisions of social security in Hong Kong in comparison with other countries and jurisdictions – similarities and differences

* *Old age and economic insecurity**

1. A global perspective on economic insecurity and poverty in old age

2. Measures to relieve economic insecurity and hardship in old age – options, strengths and weaknesses

3. Mandatory Provident Fund Vs. Old Age Pension Scheme

4. Balancing fiscal viability and financial security of old age

* *Unemployment, underemployment and economic insecurity**

1. Unemployment & underemployment: global trends & regional characteristics

2. Economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment

3. Measures to combat economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment – social security, active labour market policies & community economic development – local and overseas

4. The working poor

* *Economic insecurity arising from sickness; & Health Care**

1. Economic insecurity associated with sickness and health risks

2. Access to affordable and sustainable health care – problems and options

* *Conclusion**

1. Contributions, criticisms and issues of social security programs in combating economic insecurity and global poverty

2. Debates and controversies on future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective

3. Integration of social security and other public and social measures
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Interpersonal Violence
courses.description:
(UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.)

The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1. Critically examine the contemporary perspectives, concepts and theories on interpersonal violence.

2. Analyze causes and consequences of interpersonal violence in different contexts.

3. Apply and integrate interdisciplinary theories of violence to evaluate current policy and strategies on tackling violence.

4. Reflect on ways to combat violence and help to promote a peaceful environment.

5. Appreciate the contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Common misunderstanding and myths of interpersonal violence.

2. Contemporary perspectives and theories of violence from anthropology, education, medical science, politics, psychology, sociology and social work.

3. Nature, causes, consequences and trends of interpersonal violence.

4. The needs of victims and perpetrators of interpersonal violence.

5. Risk and protective factors of violence at personal, family, school, community and policy levels.

6. Issues of violence in regard to different genders, ages, classes, sexual orientations and cultures.

7. Current social policy and prevention programs on interpersonal violence.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
courses.description:
(UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)

This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Background and global trend of cultural diversity

a. Globalization and Ethnic Diversity

b. Culture, Ethnicity and Diversity

c. Impacts of culture on economy, health, education, immigration, social service, community development, public policy and social harmony

2. Major perspectives in cultural diversity and Intercultural Intelligence

a. “Person-in-environment” Perspective

b. Multi-culturalism

c. The Intercultural Perspective

3. Understanding ethnic and culture groups in Hong Kong

a. Major Ethnic and Cultural Groups in Hong Kong

b. Cultural Barriers and Dilemmas faced by members of ethnic minority groups

c. Stress, vulnerability, strengths and resilience in ethnic and migrant groups

d. Access and Equity

4. Cross-culture assessment and cultural formation

5. Development of cultural sensitivity, cultural competence and intercultural intelligence

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Mission-driven Social Enterprise
courses.description:
(UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203.)

This course introduces to students the field of mission-driven social enterprise, which aims to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. Through examining the best practices in social entrepreneurship, it also stimulates students to explore how social enterprise can affect policy and facilitate system change. Experiential learning elements such as visiting social enterprises and having dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users will be arranged in order to let students experience its operation, understand its practice as well as to enable students in realizing its possibilities in offering solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other societal issues. The course is valuable to students who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through this emerging field.

v Ethical Principles and Concerns

o Ethics in business

v Social Impact Assessment of Social Enterprise

o Definitions of social impact and social impact assessment

o Models of social impact assessment

o Case study

v Site Visits to Social Enterprises in HK

v Overview of Social Entrepreneurship

o Definitions of social entrepreneurship

o Dimensions of social entrepreneurship

o Modeling of social entrepreneurship process

o The prospect of social entrepreneurship

v Fundraising and Financial Management in Social Entrepreneurship

o Fundraising planning and strategies

o Ethics in fundraising

o Assessing financial capabilities and sustainability

o Strategies on financial resource management

v Opportunity Seeking and Alliance Building in Social Entrepreneurship

v The Community and Policy Impact of Social Entrepreneurship

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
courses.description:
(UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)

This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors.

Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.
courses.course_syllabus:
v Development of Social Innovation in Hong Kong Regionally and Globally

o What is Social Innovation?

o Issues of social, economic, culture and political development and Social Innovations

o Development of Social Innovation in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Mainland China, South Korea, Europe and US

v Defining Social Innovations

o Contesting definitions in Social Innovations

o Defining features of Social Innovations: social justice, empowerment, social capital, community engagement, design thinking, collaboration, etc.

o Generic social innovation processes: prompts and inspirations, imagining solutions, creativity and innovation, participation, prototyping and pilots, resource mobilization and start-ups, sustainability and scaling up

o Deep scaling and transformative social innovation

v Social Economy: From Social Enterprise to Social Solidarity Economy

o Business model and social economy model

o From Corporate Social Responsibility to Social Enterprise

o From Social Solidarity Economy to Eco-village

v Social Innovations and the Environment

o Greening the Economy and Society

o Sustainable cities and human settlement

o Food security and small holder empowerment

v Social Innovations in the Public Sector

o How policy can maximize citizen participation

o Participatory budgeting and planning

o Policy environment for social innovations

v Site Visits to Social Innovations in HK

v Case Study of Social Entrepreneurship: Dialogue Experiences

v The social, economic, political and cultural impact of Social Innovations

o Defining and measuring Impact

o Deep scaling and scaling up impacts

o Transformative Social Innovations

v Pursuing Social Innovations for the Global Futures

courses.description:
This course aims to help students acquire an understanding of the nature, principles and application of social casework. The values, knowledge and skills essential to casework intervention with individuals and families will be introduced with reference to the generalist model and the psychosocial approach. Emphasis will be put on the interplay between stressful life events, social environment, clients' individual functioning as well as their interpersonal relationships.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Nature of social casework
2. Experience of becoming a client and stage of change
3. Theoretical perspectives (Ecological perspective & Strengths perspective)
4. Practice models (Psychosocial Approach & Generalist model)
5. Social caseworker’s role
6. The helping process-Engagement and alliance building
7. The helping process- Exploration and Assessment
8. The helping process- Goal setting and planning
9. The helping process- Action
10. Crisis intervention Case Management
11. The helping process- Evaluation & Termination
12. Issues confronting beginning caseworkers
13. Review & Conclusion
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students
courses.required_readings:
Week 1: Introduction of Social Casework & What Affects Our Helping Behaviors

1. Johnson, L.C., & Yanca, S.J. (2010). Social work practice: A generalist approach (10th ed., pp. 71-97). Boston, MA: Pearson Allyn and Bacon (Chapter 4: The worker) [For Tutorial Session 1: pp. 71- 90]
2. Bogo, M. (2006). Social work practice: processes, concepts and interviewing (pp.3-34). New York: Columbia University Press. (Chapter 1- The context of practice: The social worker) [For Tutorial Session 1: pp. 3 -15 & pp. 20 - 34]
3. Reamer, F. G. (2013). Social work values and ethics (4rd ed., pp.14-46). New York: Columbia University Press (Chapter 2: The Nature of Values in Social Work)

courses.description:
The course aims at providing students with a basic understanding of the knowledge and skills of social group work. Major models and techniques of group intervention will be introduced. Attention will be given to the roles of the group worker and his/her purposeful use of group process and programmes.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. An overview on social group work
2. Knowledge base, values and principles of social group work
3. Conceptual models in social group work
4. Stages of group development
5. Pre-group planning and group formation
6. Basic group work skills
7. Group dynamics in the beginning, transitional, working and ending phases of a group
8. Evaluation of group achievement
9. Application of social group work in Chinese community to work with different clientele groups
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students
courses.required_readings:
1. An overview of social group Work
- Anderson, J. (1997). Social work with groups – a process model. New York: Longman. (Chapter 2 – Historical Perspective)
- Breton, M. (1990). Learning from social group work traditions. Social Work with Groups, 13(3), 107-119
- Yan, M.C. (2001). Reclaiming the social in social group work: An experience of a community center in Hong Kong. Social Work with Groups 24 (3/4), 53-66.
- 梁玉麒、游達裕、區結蓮、張敏思 (2011)。香港社工小組工作前瞻。載於梁玉麒、張敏思、游達裕、歐結蓮編。千帆並舉：社會 工作小組新貌。香港：策馬文創有限公司出版。

2. Knowledge base of social group work
- Breton, M. (2004). An empowerment perspective. In Garvin, C. D., Gutierrez, L. M. & Galinsky, M. J. (eds.). Handbook of social work with groups. New York, London: The Guilford Press.
- Johnson, D. W. & Johnson, F. P. (2003). Joining together – Group theory and group skills (7th ed.). Boston: Allyn and Bacon. (Chapter 2: Experiential learning)
- Steinberg, D. M. (2014). The mutual-aid approach to working with groups: helping people help each other. (3rd ed.). London: Routledge. (Chapter 1 – The mutual-aid approach in social work with groups)
- Tropman, J. E. (2004). An ecological-systems perspective. In Garvin,
C. D., Gutierrez, L. M. & Galinsky, M. J. (eds.). Handbook of social work with groups. New York, London: The Guilford Press.

3. Conceptual models in social group work
- Cohen, M. B. & Mullender, A. (2006). The personal in the political: Exploring the group work continuum from individual to social change goals. Social Work with Groups, 28, 3, 187-204.
- Gladding, S. T. (1999). Group work: a counseling specialty. Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Merrill. (Chapter 2 – Types of Group work)
- Papell, C. P. & Rothman, B. (1980). Social group work models: Possession and heritage. In Alissi, A. S. (ed.). Perspectives on social group work – A book of readings. New York: Free Press, pp.116-132.
- Papell, C. P. & Rothman, B. (1980). Relating the mainstream mode of social work with groups to group psychotherapy and the structured group approach. Social Work with Groups, 3, 2, 5-23.

4. Therapeutic / Change factors in social group work
- Crouch, E. C., Bloch, S., & Wanlass, J. (1994). Therapeutic factors: Interpersonal and intrapersonal mechanisms. In Fuhriman, A. & Burlingame, G. M. (eds.), Handbook of group psychotherapy: An empirical and clinical synthesis (pp. 269-315). New York: Wiley.
- Garvin, C. D. (1997). Contemporary group work (3rd ed.). Boston, MA: Allyn & Bacon. (Chapter 6 – Enhancing the member’s use of therapeutic factors in groups)
- Yalom, I. D. (1998). The therapeutic factors: What it is that heals. In
Yalom, B. (ed.). The Yalom reader – Selections from the work of a master therapist and storyteller. New York: Basic Books.

5. Group dynamics
- Johnson, D. W. & Johnson, F. P. (2009). Joining together – Group theory and group skills (10th ed.). Boston: Allyn and Bacon. (Chapter 1– Group dynamics)
- Toseland, R. W. & Rivas, R. F. (2005). An introduction to group work practice (5th ed.). Boston: Pearson/Allyn and Bacon. (Chapter 3 – Understanding group dynamics)

6. Group development stages

courses.description:
This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge and skills of community work. It will examine the basic concepts, theoretical assumptions, values and skills of community work. Modes of intervention in different settings and current debates and challenges in community practice will also be examined.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What is Community & Community Work?

2. Principle and values of community work

3. History and current situation of community work in Hong Kong

4. Skills of Community Work

5. Skills in working with community (I): Knowing the Community

6. Skills in working with communities (II): Dynamics Analysis and Strategy Planning

7. Skills in working with Community (III): Community Education and Meeting

8. Community work intervention models (I): Locality and organizing the neighbourhood

9. Community work intervention models (II): Advocacy and Social Action

10. Community work intervention models (III): Community Care

11. Future and Prospect of Community Work
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work Field Laboratory
courses.description:
This course adopts a laboratory training format to provide students with opportunities to experience and become familiar with events encountered in the field. The primary emphases of the course are helping students acquire essential communication and intervention skills and develop more sensitivity and acceptance towards human nature and to reflect upon their attitudes in the helping process.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to purposes and functions of field laboratory
2. Helping Attitudes
3. Helping skills for working with individuals, groups and community
4. Use of field instruction
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

1. Corey, M. S., & Corey, G. (2021). Becoming a helper (8th ed.). Belmont, CA: Brooks/Cole.

3. Hardcastle, D. A. with Powers, P. R. & Wenocur, S. (2011). Community Practice: Theories and Skills for Social Workers. New York: Oxford University Press.

courses.description:
This course aims to help students acquire knowledge and skills in clinical social work practice. Specifically, it attempts to familiarize students with current major approaches in working with individuals, families and groups and help students develop an integrative perspective in direct practice.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction and basic issues in clinical social work

． The basic philosophy in clinical social work

． Relationship between theory, social work practice and research

． The personhood of worker and the therapeutic process

II. Clinical social work theories and practice

． Person-centered therapy

． Cognitive therapy

． Behavioral therapy and SSLD (Skills, Strategies, Learning and Development)

． Psychodynamic therapy

． Gestalt therapy

III. Special issues and summing up

． Ethical issues in clinical social work practice

． Cultural issues in clinical social work practice

1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.description:
Macro social work is a blend of social awareness, welfare practice reflection and organizing skills. The course aims to equip students with the basic knowledge and skills in performing the above functions through examining relevant macro social work theories and approaches. Emphasis will be put on the changing practice context for macro practice, service integration, community organizing and networking, and how the welfare of the vulnerable group within the larger society can be promoted.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to

1. apply knowledge and skills in performing macro social work practice;
2. have a basic understanding of the main social policy issues (poverty, social development) in Hong Kong that affect the welfare conditions of the people in general and the disadvantaged groups in particular; and
3. understand and apply strategies, skills, and determinants of policy advocacy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of Macro Social Work and Macro social work values: equality, social justice, human rights, liberty, freedom (autonomy, self-determination), participation
2. Theories of Macro Social Work (I): from neoliberalism to Marxism
3. Theories of Macro Social Work (II): post-structuralist macro social work
4. Gender sensitive practice – changing women, changing men
5. Anti-racist social work
6. Globalisation and International Social Work
7. Social Development and Green Social Work
8. Macro social work and new social movement
9. The Future of Macro Social Work
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

Lecture 1: Overview of Macro Social Work

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Welfare Administration
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of social welfare agency administration. Basic management theories, principles and methods in administration, service planning, administrative structure and operation, personnel and financial management, and evaluation of social welfare agencies will be discussed.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Defining welfare service management
2. The nature of organization in different worldviews
3. Features and characteristics of human service organizations & value and ethics in welfare service management
4. Management v.s. managerialism
5. Accountability
6. Program planning
7. Performance monitoring
8. Quality management
9. Program evaluation
10. Managing resources
11. Participatory management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work Research
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the nature, concepts and principles of social work research. The research process, including problem formulation, research design, data collection and analysis, and presentation of findings will be examined. Students are expected to be able to conduct social work research and make effective use of research findings.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Social Work Research

2. The Ethical, Political, and Cultural Context of Social Work Research (Evidence-Based Approach)

3. Problem Formulation & Writing Research Paper

4. Measurement

5. Design of Research

6. Samples & Sampling Method

7. Survey & Secondary Data

8. Program Evaluation

9. Introduction to Hypothesis Test & Quantitative Analyses

10. Introduction to Qualitative Research
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.description: This course aims to facilitate student’s understanding of the contribution of social planning and policy formulation to the solution, control or amelioration of social problems on the macro-level. A knowledge of the key elements of decision-making; an understanding of what is involved when designing social service programmes consistent with the economic capacity, cultural values and standards of modern societies, such as Hong Kong will be introduced.
courses.course_syllabus:
A. Introduction: Social Policy and the Social Production of Welfare

B. Theories of Welfare / Ideology of Social Policy

1. The construction of social policy in Hong Kong – Can productivism be enhanced by authoritarianism?

2. Left Wing Social Policy and the Third Way

3. Feminisms in Social Policy

4. Political Economy, moral economy and Marxist Critique of Social Policy

C. Social Policy Process and Issues

1. Social quality and social policy: What does it inform us in Hong Kong?

2. Social inequality, redistribution and the privatisation of welfare

3. Social Policy and Citizenship

4. Social Policy Analysis

D. Selected Social Policy Analysis

1. Poverty and Social Inequality in Hong Kong

2. Ageing, Ageism and Social Policy

3. Education, Social Investment and Youth Social Mobility

E. Conclusion: Social Policy Practice
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Field Instruction I

meetings.instructor:
Dr. AU YEUNG Kwok Wai Eric, 
Mr. DIN Wai Bun

courses.description:
The course provides opportunities for students to put theories learnt in class into practice in an agency setting and under supervision. Students are expected to apply : (a) methods of direct service to clients – casework, group work and community organization; (b) knowledge and use of community resources; (c) tasks akin to agency administration – planning, budgeting, staffing, etc., and (d) tools for administration – writing of reports, letters, accounting, use of research findings, conducting meetings, etc.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: SOWK2020, 2210, 2220, 2230 and 2430
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Familiarizing with the community: agency and community visits

2. Learning needs identification and selection of assignments

3. Formulating case assessment reports, group and/or project proposals

4. Implementing case/group/project

5. Evaluation on case/group/project

6. Reflecting on self as social worker
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Final field instruction evaluation

2. Ongoing feedback from placement agencies and students
courses.required_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Student Orientated Teaching II
courses.description:
This is a capstone course for students to integrate their learning in various aspects in social work and prepare themselves for the future career in social work. The course is a small group teaching course designed for final year students. It aims to help students reflect on and apply the values, knowledge, and skills of social work practice. Students are required to take initiative in their own learning through library research, critical examination of relevant materials, intellectual exchange of ideas, and sharing of personal experiences.

Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction and overview
2. Review on meaningful and significant experience in practicum
3. Need assessment and clientele identification of the project
4. Literature review on target clientele and knowledge concerned
5. Conceptualization and intervention
6. Conculsion and consolidation of learning
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students
courses.required_readings: Reference materials in previous course, library search for relevant literature, local documents, as well as reference materials in field practicum can be used for the preparation of the presentation and the individual project paper.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work Guided Research
courses.description:
This is an advanced capstone course for students to integrate their learning in various aspects in Social Work. Students will have to plan and conduct a guided research on an approved topic on local or overseas welfare system and practice, and write a project report under the supervision and guidance of a faculty member with relevant specialty.

(Advisory: For major students with CGPA of not lower than 3.3 only)
courses.course_syllabus: To be confirmed between the supervisor and the student.

1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings: To be confirmed between the supervisor and the student.
courses.recommended_readings: To be confirmed between the supervisor and the student.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Global Justice, International Order and Policy Building
courses.description:
Globalization not only brings significant impact on economic development but also significantly redefines norms and values. From the Universal Declaration of Human Rights being ratified in 1949 to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Goals adopted in 2015, international mechanisms, such as the United Nations, have constantly constructed social values under prerequisite global power order among nations. Globalization shapes international value and policy setting, political power among nation states and intergovernmental organizations influences local policy environment that goes beyond the regulation of nation state.
This course offers an opportunity for the students to understand three levels of human rights development: ideology, political interplay, and policy formulation. Through exploring the causes and constructions of human rights, this course sets the grounds for students to comprehend knowledge on the current human rights and policy debates concerning social citizenship in relations to the underlying process of the international mechanisms and power relationships. Judging from the debates, students will also explore and analyze globalization and the regional impact on a variety of actors in social policy and on local policymaking.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Globalization and human rights development

2. Dimensions of human rights and their interplay

3. The development and making of social policy

4. International values and their application on local policymaking

5. The roles and functions of international human rights mechanisms and international organizations

6. Regional mechanisms in human right governance and regional policy setting

7. Poverty, human rights and humanitarianism

8. Women’s rights, gender equality and movements

9. What is global equality and justice: who defines whose rights?

10. Culture, religion and human rights: co-existence or contradictory?

11. Putting discussions into action: how human rights organizations influence policy

12. Globalization, glocalization, localization: the future impact of globalization on local policy
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students

2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire

3. External examiner report
courses.required_readings: Stuart, A. (2012). Putting Universal Human Rights to Work: Policy Actions in the Struggle for Social Justice. New York: Gordian Knot Books.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Employment, Labour, Poverty and Social Policy
courses.description: The course aims to help students understand the current labour and employment issues in Hong Kong and other contemporary societies internationally. Special attention will be given to economic insecurity and unemployment issues and how these issues inter-related to the issues of poverty. Different service provision and strategy of the governments will be reviewed, and current debates on the philosophy and the future direction of labour and employment services will be analyzed.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Changing Employment of Hong Kong

2. Labour Legislation and Labour Services in Hong Kong

3. Employment Services in Hong Kong and overseas

4. Training and Education Services in HK and overseas

5. Labour and Poverty: Services to the unemployed and marginal workers

6. Current Labour Issues and debates
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students

2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire

3. External examiner report

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Law and Social Work
courses.description: This course aims to introduce students to an understanding of the Basic Law, the legal system, court proceedings and laws relevant to matrimony, criminal justice and social welfare in Hong Kong. Students are expected to apply the relevant legal knowledge to different social work settings, and be able to review roles of social work in the legal systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Nature & Basic Principles of Law : Hong Kong Common Laws & Basic Law
2. Social Workers Registration Ordinance and professional conduct
3. Criminal Law
4. Family Law:
- Child Custody & Ancillary Relief
- Domestic and Cohabitation Relationship
- Violence Ordinance and Spouse/Cohabitant Battering
5. Law for Protection of Children and Juveniles :
- PCJO and Child Welfare (guardianship, wardship, adoption and child abuse)
6. Mental Health Law :
- compulsory admission, conditional discharge and community rehabilitation
- guardianship
7. HK Employment Law
8. Anti-Discrimination Laws
9. Judicial Review
10. Application of legal knowledge in Social Work Practice : Case Discussion
11. Revision, Report drafting in court procedures & Roles and Responsibilities of Social Workers
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar I: Family-centered Social Work
courses.description:
This course aims to provide students with an integrative and family-centered framework in working with families and individuals. Focus is given to the understanding of family-centered practice as a holistic approach that integrates the various social work methods in the helping process. In line with the social work values, it is based on the beliefs and practices that treat families with dignity and respect. Guided with these beliefs and principles, the changing family ideologies, policies on family, the adequacy of family services in Hong Kong and the formulation of an integrative and family centered service delivery system will be critically examined.

Advisory: For majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1: What is Family-centered Practice?
2: Basic Beliefs, Theoretical Base and Principles of Family-centered Practice
3: Interventions and services in Family-Centered Practice
4: Family-Centered Practice with Post-Divorce Families
5: Family Centered Practice in Psychiatric Rehabilitation Services
6: Family-Centered Practice in Rehabilitation Services
7: Family-Centered Practice in Residential Child Care Services
8: Implementation of Family-centered Social Work Practice in Different Service Settings
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar II: Social Work with Young People
courses.description:
This course aims to provide students with an in-depth understanding of social work practice with young people. Apart from familiarizing students with the philosophies, historical development and operational structures of youth services in Hong Kong, emphasis is placed on studying the needs and characteristics of local young people, as well as the major concepts, theories and interventional methods when working with young people and their families. Current policy issues related to welfare and rights of young people will also be discussed.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding the concepts of youth and youth-at-risk;

2. A profile of youth in Hong Kong and its implications for youth policy and practice

3. Theoretical foundations of the matrix model to understanding youth

4. Understanding the major youth social work approaches and practices
• The historical development of youth services in Hong Kong
• Current youth social work practices in Hong Kong
• Major youth social work approaches

5. The helping relationship, process and skills in social work with young people

6. Career Development- self journey

7. A strengthen approach to youth work

8. Contentious issues in youth work
• Self-harm and suicide, mental health
• Substance abuse
• Social withdrawal
• Juvenile delinquency
• Teenage sexuality & pregnancy
• Bullying and victim

9. Use of art in youth work practice

10. Youth social work in transition: Opportunities and challenges in times of rapid sociopolitical transformation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar III: Social Work with Older People
courses.description:
This course aims to equip students with a systematic, humanistic, and integrative perspective when working with older people in interdisciplinary settings. Apart from providing students with information on the psychosocial, mental, economic, and health conditions of older people, this course introduces to students some major gerontological theories, policies and services (e.g. home-based services, community-based services, long-term care services and financial aids), with a focus on empowering older people. Also, current policy issues related to the advancement of betterment of older people will be critically examined and discussed.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Conceptual definitions in the study of aging
2. Ageism - Prejudices and biases against aging and older persons
3. Major gerontological theories
4. Understand the process of aging from a biopsychosocial perspective
5. Aging population and its impact on society
6. Care Plan and Continuum of Care
7. Dying and Death in Old Age
8. Elder abuse & Depression and suicide in older adults
9. Employment, reemployment and social security issues for older adults
10. Impact of aging on family, Caregiving and caregiver burden, and Social support services to caregiver
11. Gerontechnology
12. Residential Care Homes - Challenges & Future Development
13. Cognitive issues and Dementia
14. Active and successful aging
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar IV: Social Work with People with Special Needs
courses.description:
This course aims to help students understand the psychological as well as the socio-political aspects of people with special needs. The course addresses the social construction of disability and discusses major concepts and critical issues relevant to service design in a contemporary context, with a view to creating an enabling environment for persons with special needs. Students are also expected to familiarize themselves with related policies and services in Hong Kong, and be able to make critical appraisals on the extent to which current social work services meet the needs of persons with special needs.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Social work intervention theories related to disability

2. Social work and disability

3. Psychosocial aspects of people with disabilities

4. Families with people with disabilities

5. Roles of different professions

6. Case management and service coordination

7. Managed care, empowerment and legal issues

8. Social construction of disabilities
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar V: Poverty and Social Exclusion
courses.description: This course aims to examine the poverty and social exclusion problems from both a local and a global context. Theories of human capital, social capital, social exclusion, and globalization will be introduced to understand the causes and impacts of poverty and social exclusion. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to apply relevant theories in the analysis and practice to alleviate the poverty and social exclusion situations of different vulnerable populations, for example welfare recipients, women, working poor and ethnic minorities. Recent trends and issues on poverty and poverty alleviation will be discussed in the social context of Hong Kong and the changing regional and global environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Impact of globalization and regionalization on economic insecurity
2) Poverty situations in Hong Kong, China and other developing countries under globalization
3) Concepts & Measurement of Poverty
4) Concept of social exclusion and anti-social exclusion policies and programmes
5) Poverty alleviation strategies I: Education & human capital investment
6) Poverty alleviation strategies II: Building social capital
7) Poverty alleviation strategies III: Work First – job creation, job subsidy and workfare
8) Poverty alleviation strategies IV: Social security and Minimum Wage
9) Evaluation of different poverty alleviation and anti-social exclusion policies, programmes and projects in Hong Kong
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar VII: Art-based Social Work Practice
courses.description:
This course combines the concepts of expressive arts in healing and basic working principles of arts-based social work practice. It is not creative arts therapy training, but exploring the resources of expressive arts for facilitating social work practice. The course is designed for social work students who are interested in learning the application of arts in counseling, group, and community work. It is also appropriate for those wishing to awake the seeds of creativity and make use of their inner resources for both personal growth and professional development.

Expressive arts are powerful verbal, nonverbal, and imaginative tools for self-expression and communication. This arts-based social work practice is action-oriented and process-focused. Students have an opportunity to experiment the use of arts for creative exploration and self-understanding so that they can synthesize their personal experience with conceptual learning.

Advisory: For majors only
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course introduction

- course objectives/program content/course requirements

2. Healing power/resources of arts

- means of communication

- dialogue between conscious & unconscious

- container for emotions/ instincts

- avenue for insights

- transforming process of personal growth

3. Media Exploration

- Therapeutic effects of different art modalities

- Creative exploration

- Art facilitation

4. Theoretical foundations of using creative arts for healing, health, and well-being

- Psychoanalytical

- Psychodynamic

- Humanistic

- Contemporary

5. Self-understanding through mask-making

- Functions & Techniques of mask- making and self-exploration

6. Introduction to Music Therapy

7. Application of creative arts in social work practice

- Individual counseling

- Group work

- Community setting

8. Outcome Measurement and Evaluation Measures

- Research approaches and methods

- Practice outcome

- Case studies

9. Closure and Ending

- Consolidation and termination

- Techniques of leading the last session

10. Professional Pathway: Training & Supervision
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Ongoing feedback from students
2. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation, followed by reflective discussions with students
3. Final course and teaching evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire will be conducted by the department
4. External Examiner's Report

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar VIII: Gender and Sexuality in Social Work Practice
courses.description: Through examining the situations of women and people of diverse gender identities in local and global contexts, this seminar course aims to develop students’ interest and understanding towards different trending gender issues and integrating these issues in social welfare policymaking and social work practices. Critical concepts in social work, such as social justice, equality, power and empowerment, would be re-examined and analysed under various gender discourses. Students would then acquire skills and knowledge on assessing social policy and social work practices from a gender perspective, and be able to integrate global gender debates in local policy agenda and social work practices.
courses.course_syllabus:
Sex-positive social work practice
Feminist social work practice
LGBTQ+ affirmative social work practice
Sexual identity development
Agency visit
Parents and families of LGBTQ+ youth
Gender-based violence
Intimacy and relationships
Reproductive rights
Sexual health
Transgender and gender diversity
LGBTQ+ community development
Group presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
The following evaluation methods will be used in collecting feedback from students:

* Students’ responses during classes
* Informal interactions with students
* Mid-term course evaluation
* Formal course evaluation at the end of the course

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar IX: Family Therapy
courses.description:
This course aims to help students understand the basic assumption and theoretical foundation of family therapy. The values, knowledge and skills essential to family practice will be introduced with a systemic perspective. Focus will be set on familiarizing students with the major approaches in working with families and the application of family therapy in different settings and with various target populations.
Advisory: For Majors only.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Origins and evolution of family therapy
2. Fundamental concepts of family therapy
3. Classic schools of family therapy
• Satir family therapy
• Bowen family systems therapy
• Structural family therapy
• Strategic family therapy

4. Contemporary developments in family therapy
• Postmodernism and social construction
• Solution-focused family therapy
• Narrative therapy

5. Assessment and engagement
6. Working with children
7. Working with adolescents
8. Working with couples
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation
2. Final course and teaching evaluation
3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar X: Research Seminar
courses.description:
This course is designed to provide students with basic knowledge and skills on social work research and statistics. Value and ethical issues in the scientific approach to social work practice will be addressed. The course will also focus on various statistical procedures used in social work research, including SPSS as an efficient and effective tool for this purpose.
(Advisory: For Majors only.)
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of research process

2. Ethical issues in social work research

3. Measurement

4. Application of different statistical methods

5. Introduction to SPSS basic operation

6. Descriptive Statistics

7. Introduction to Inferential Statistics

8. Qualitative research design

9. Qualitative data analysis

1. Mid-term course and teaching evaluation

2. Final course and teaching evaluation

3. Ongoing feedback from students

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Family in Changing Society
courses.description: This course examines different theories in conceptualizing families such as structural-functionalism, systems theory and the post-modernist’s view. The recent changes in family life in Hong Kong and in Chinese society connected to the changing socioeco- cultural context will be investigated. Particular attention will be given to the developmental needs and problems of families as well as the stress, coping and resilience of families in different stages. Culture and gender issues, the roles of social services and educational system, current problems and challenges confronting family development in Hong Kong will also be scrutinized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to :
1. Understand the changing conceptualizations of family, family normality and family pathology by examining different family theories.
2. Know the recent changes in family life and family forms in Hong Kong and other Chinese societies connected to the changing socio-cultural context.
3. Apply the theories in examining the implications of the social changes on individual and family well-beings.
4. Make critical reflection on the gender, class and cultural issues, the role of social services and educational system, current problems and challenges confronting family development in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Different Theories in Conceptualizing Families
• Structural Functionalism
• Family-Systems Theory and Family Development Theory
• Social Constructionism
• Feminism
• What is “family” in traditional Chinese culture?
Part II: Recent Changes in Family Life in Hong Kong and Other Chinese-Societies (selective topics for lectures and student presentations)
• Divorce evolution and post-divorce family relationships
• Work and Family Interface in Hong Kong
• Global householding and cross-border living families
• The changing meanings and patterns of intimate relationships in Hong Kong : Marriage, cohabitation and singlehood
• The changing meanings and patterns of parenthood, childhood and grandparenthood in Hong Kong
• Technology advancement and family life
• Debates on the marriage rights and family rights of LGBTI
• Negotiation of family relationships in a politically divisive social context
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Theories and Practice of Family Counselling
courses.description: This course aims to help students understand the basic assumption and theoretical foundation of family counselling and to help students acquiring a systemic perspective. The assumptions and rationales underlying major family counselling approaches such as structural and strategic family therapy, solution-focused therapy and narrative therapy will be discussed. Focuses will be lay on the application of family counselling in different social contexts, such as social service organizations, schools, hospitals, maternal and child health care centres.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to:

1. Understand the theoretical foundation, basic concepts and skills of the approaches in family counseling that have been taught in the course.

2. Understand the applicability of different perspectives in family counseling in the socio-cultural context of Hong Kong.

3. Acquire an enhanced sensitivity on cultural and ethical issues in the actual practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Ethical decision making in family counselling and therapy
- History and development of family therapy
- Classical models of family therapy
- Postmodernist models of family therapy
- A common factors approach in family therapy
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Theories and Practice of Family Education

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This course examines the assumption and theoretical foundation of family education. It aims to help students understand different perspectives in family education and its implications for practice. Theories and concepts of parenting, adult learning and parenthood will be examined. Practical skills of assessing family and parental needs, curriculum and programme designs, and strategies in advocacy of family and parent education programmes will also be tackled. Focuses will be lay on the application of family education in different social contexts, such as social service organizations, schools, hospitals, maternal and child health care centres.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to family education
- Cultural perspectives on family education
- Approaches on family education : Transmission perspective
- Approaches on family education: Transaction perspective
- Approaches on family education : Transformation perspective
- Models of couple education
- Body, Sexuality and family education
- Applications of family education
- Emotionality and family education
- Applications of family education
- Conclusion: Critical reflections and future development
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.
