courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Fundamental Theories of Social Policy
courses.description: This course aims to enable students to have an understanding of basic concepts and theories in social policy. The content of the course focuses on basic ideas and theories of different social policy approaches e.g., human needs and rights, social exclusion, social development, and social quality. In emphasizing the theories of social policy and social welfare, the course is to enable students to have solid basic social policy understanding with reference to international experiences and value systems. Students will be facilitated to develop social policy understanding and capabilities of critical analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1) Understand different theories and frameworks of social policy and welfare provision.
2) Critically and conceptually analyze current social welfare policies, procedures, and programs.
3) Describe and critically analyze major fields of social welfare provision from a global and context-sensitive perspective.
4) Discuss and critically analyze current policy debates, trends, and ethical issues in specific fields of welfare provision presented in the course including the implications for social work practice and promoting social justice and social change.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Theories of social policy and social welfare
- Human needs and rights
- Social exclusion; social development; and social quality
courses.feedback_evaluation: Common Department course evaluation exercises
courses.required_readings:
Blakemore, Ken and Louise Warwick-Booth (2013) Social policy: an introduction. 4th ed. Maidenhead : Open University Press, McGraw-Hill Education. (chapter 1)

Bradshaw, J.R. (2013). A taxonomy of social need. In Cookson, R., Sainsbury, R. & Glendinning, C. (eds.). Jonathan Bradshaw on Social Policy: Selecting Writings 1972-2011. York: York Publishing Services, pp. 1-11.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Policy and Social Welfare in China
courses.description: This course introduces the development of social welfare policy in China. The relationship between social welfare policy and changing ideology, the differences in social welfare policy between urban and rural areas, and specific fields of social welfare policy in China, including social assistance policy, social insurance policy, employment policy, education policy, medical health care policy, housing policy, and social policies related to children, elders and disabled persons will be examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work, Master of Social Work and MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Globalisation, Welfare Theories and Welfare Regimes: Locating China’s Welfare at a Time of Change
- Globalisation, Welfare Regimes and Welfare Changes: Locating Social policy in China in a Global Context
- China’s Welfare Regime: Institutional framework for social welfare and social policy in China in a Global World
Part II: Social and Economic Reforms: Implications for Social Policy
- China’s Economic Reforms: Development and Transformation
- Social Development in China: Challenges for a Harmonious Society
- China’s Welfare System: Changes and Problems
Part III: Specific Social Policy in China
- Social Security and Poverty Reduction
- Health Care Policy with particular respect to Urban Health Care Reforms
- Population Ageing and Elderly Care
- Professionalization of Social Work
Part IV: Conclusion and Course Evaluation
- Social Welfare and Social Policy in China: Which Way Ahead?
courses.feedback_evaluation:
A mid-term evaluation will be conducted in approximately the 7th teaching week. Students are encouraged to give feedback in this evaluation so as to improve the learning experience in the second half of the semester. Throughout the learning process, students are welcome to share their learning experience and difficulty with the instructor whenever needed so as to make immediate improvement.

Course evaluation will be conducted in the second last teaching week.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Theories, Social Welfare and Social Work
courses.description: This course aims to examine the classical and contemporary social theories, particularly the evolution of the theories of modernism and postmodernism in the domain of social science. It also investigates the changing concepts and functions of social welfare that transform from the residual conception of social welfare that emphasizes self-reliance, informal support, charity and subsistence to the institutional conception of social welfare that stresses collective responsibilities, community care and development of human potentials. The major focus is to help students examine and critically analyze the implications of changing social theories on the development of social welfare and social work practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of Social Theories, Social Welfare and Social Work
2. Theorizing Social Welfare and Social Work: Modernism and Postmodernism
- Enlightenment and progress: Liberalism, Marxism and the modernity thesis
- Against Enlightenment: questions on power and knowledge
- Post-Enlightenment problematics: new social divisions and recent economic developments
3. Theory in Context: Current Issues in Social Welfare and Social Work in Hong Kong
4. Conclusion: Directions for Theory & Practice in Social Welfare and Social Work
- Cross-cultural social welfare and social work? static, passive and dynamic models
- Modeling new directions for social welfare and social work
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Research in Social Welfare and Social Work
courses.description: This course is designed to provide the students with an understanding and appreciation of scientific and evidence-based approach to build knowledge for professional social work practice and evaluate practice in a variety of social services settings. Research processes examine in stages from problem formulation to analyses. The course focuses on how research problems are formulated, hypotheses or research questions are derived, the specific designs that practice researchers may use in addressing given research topics, and data collection and analysis approaches, and evaluating the research of others. The theoretical concepts, approaches, methods and issues in qualitative and quantitative research are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. Develop an understanding on the conceptual foundations and methodological tools of quantitative and qualitative social research and its application to the fields of social welfare and social work.
2. Identify and discuss ethical issues related to research design and the reporting and use of research results.
3. Select appropriate quantitative and/or qualitative research methods to study a vulnerable population or a social problem, and be aware of their strengths and weaknesses.
4. Become familiar with basic qualitative and quantitative data analysis techniques in social work research.
5. Critically discuss and evaluate service programs, welfare policies, and research of others.
6. Conduct social work research at the postgraduate level in an independent manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to Social Welfare/Work Research
- Scientific Inquiry, Research Process, and Problem Formulation
- Measurement
- Design of Research
- Sampling Methods
- Survey Methods
- Quantitative Data Analyses I
- Quantitative Data Analyses II
- Introduction to Qualitative Research
- EBP-Revisited
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students
2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire
courses.required_readings: Rubin, A., & Babbie, E. (2017). Research methods for social work (9th ed). Boston: Cengage Learning.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Advanced Social Work Practice
courses.description: This course aims to help students understand the contemporary theories and knowledge of social work practice as well as the application of these theories in working with individuals, couples, families, groups, organizations and/or communities. The current state of social work practice in different settings and with various target populations will be discussed.

courses.learning_outcomes:

2. Apply these theories in their practice

- The psychodynamic paradigm: The application of attachment theory in social work practice

- The post-modernist paradigm: The application of narrative therapy in social work practice

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Innovation and Innovative Practice for Social Work
courses.description:
This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations and innovative practices in tackling local and global challenges and uncertainties. Special attention will be given to the innovation and practices performed by social workers and social service agencies. Social innovation means accomplishing more with less, working together, leveraging resources, sharing data, and creating models for change that are sustainable. Social innovation is a broad concept and practice that could be implemented through social intrapreneurship or social entrepreneurship. Innovative practice means the introduction of new ideas, services, processes, procedures or structures into a system or organization to make a change for good. The innovative practice is a process moving internally designed or externally created knowledge into action. The essence of social innovation and innovative practice for social work is a process of planned social change in creating social values while its ultimate goal is to induce significant social impacts for the betterment of people’s quality of life.

In this course, students will acquire knowledge, strategies and practice models of social innovations, social intrapreneurship, and social entrepreneurship. The scope of social innovations includes those in NGOs, non-profit organizations, communities, business and public sector. Experiential learning, such as site/ programme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, social intrapreneurs or service users, will be integrated along the course delivery. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-how for students who would like to develop innovative actions to change society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

The following topics will be covered:
- Development of Social Innovation in Hong Kong, Asia and the World
• What is social innovation?
• Issues of social, economic, culture and political development and Social Innovations
• Development of social innovation in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Mainland China, South Korea, Europe and the US
- Defining Social Innovation
• Contesting definitions of social innovations
• Defining features of social innovations: social justice, empowerment, social capital, community engagement, design thinking, collaboration, etc.
- Strategy, Method and Know-how of Social Innovation
• Generic social innovation processes: prompts and inspirations, imagining solutions, creativity and innovation, participation, prototyping and pilots, resource mobilization and start-ups, sustainability and scaling up
• Deep scaling and transformative social innovation
• Social Entrepreneurship
• Hybrid of macro social work practice and business skills and activities
• Operating as social bricoleurs, social constructionists, social engineers
• Recognizing opportunities, assess risks according to the scale of change
• Creating social value and meet social needs in a sustainable way
• Alleviate social problems, enhance social conditions, and promote social change
• Combining social needs with social assets and create social impact
• Joining forces with community members, government, and business partners to start ventures that creatively meet social needs
- Social Intrapreneurship
• Identifying and implementing new ways to address social problems within organizations
• Designing more effective and efficient operations and partnerships
- Innovative Social Work Practice
• Understanding complex and uncertain organizational context for achieving successfully intended outcomes
• Social dimension: norms, values, expectations, perceptions, and attitudes of members of organization
• Knowledge about the factors that act as barriers and facilitators to successful implementation of innovative practice
- Innovative Practice I: Social Economy -- From Social Enterprise to Social Solidarity Economy
• Business model and social economy model
• From corporate social responsibility to social enterprise
• From social solidarity economy to eco-village
- Innovative Practice II: Mindfulness/Art/Play/Dance/Food and Meals/Animal-Assisted Programme
• Body, mind and, spiritual
• Food and Meals/ Alternative living
- Site Visits to Social Innovations in HK
- Case Study of Social Entrepreneurship: Dialogue Experiences
- Case study of Social Intrapreneurship: Sharing Kitchen (共廚家作)
- Pursuing Social Innovations and Innovative Practice for social workers

- Students’ reaction during classes

- Formal course evaluation at end of course
- Reflection of teacher

courses.description: This course examines different theoretical perspectives in conceptualizing and managing mental health problems and mental disorders, with its emphasis on the contributions of the socio-cultural perspectives in this area. Selected critical issues in mental health and mental disorders (e.g. gender, class effect) are examined in an in-depth manner and its implications for social work practice are discussed.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Programme Evaluation
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to enable students to acquire the knowledge and skills in conducting programme evaluation for human service programmes. The course will examine programme evaluation as an integral part of professional practice within the human services, and will introduce students to the concepts and methods in conducting programme evaluation from the conceptualization stage to the outcome stage of human service programmes. Special topics such as cost-effectiveness analysis, cost-benefit analysis, development of performance indicators, statistical process control, benchmarking, reengineering, single-subject designs, group designs, etc., will be discussed, and issues related to conducting programme evaluation for human services will be examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Social Work (MSW), MA in Family Counselling and Family Education (MAFCFE), MA in Social Service Management (MASSM), MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare (MPhil-PhD) and Master of Social Science in Social Work (MSSc)
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction and Course Overview
- Typology of Program Evaluation
- Process of Program Evaluation
- Introduction to Formative Design
- Introduction to Summative Design I
- Introduction to Summative Design II
- Measurement and Research Design
- Data Analysis
- Presenting evaluation findings
- Building up model for change
courses.feedback_evaluation:
A mid-term evaluation will be conducted in approximately the 5th teaching week. Students are encouraged to give feedback in this evaluation so as to improve the learning experience in the second half of the semester.
Final course evaluation will be conducted in the second last teaching week.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Welfare and Social Policy
courses.description: The course aims at helping students to examine the changing conceptions of social welfare, major theories of social welfare and social policy, the role and functions of social welfare in meeting needs and tackling social problems. Major social welfare systems of the West and East Asia (Hong Kong, China, etc.) will be introduced. The course will put emphasis on the development of social welfare programmes in Hong Kong in relation to poverty, unemployment, family problems and other social deprivations. Social work as a helping profession will be discussed, with particular attention on how they address and advocate for the cause of the vulnerable populations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1. Discuss the relationship between private troubles and public issues.
2. Discuss the changing concepts of social welfare.
3. Understand basic values and philosophy underlying social welfare.
4. Have basic knowledge in social policy planning, process, analysis and evaluation.
5. Develop a social and macro view on social work practice.
6. Make use of the knowledge acquired in class to discuss and assess current policy
practice and social welfare program in Hong Kong critically.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Why Social Policy? Paying for a Just and Civilized Society
- Major Concepts and Issues in Welfare Policy
- Social Service and Controversies of the Welfare State
- Welfare Systems in Hong Kong and Mainland China
- Public Assistance, Social Security, and Poverty Relief
- Housing Policies
- Policies around Education
- Health Care
- Gender, Reproduction, and Family Wellbeing
- Elderly Care
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course instructor will collect feedback from students half way through the course, for enhancement of course content and delivery in accordance to students’ learning needs. Students can also talk to the course instructor on their learning experience and find the course instructor for academic discussion whenever necessary.

courses.description: This course helps students develop into ethical social workers and equips them with adequate legal knowledge. It helps students understand the philosophical foundation, practice principles, professional values and ethics of the social work profession. The course also introduces students to the Basic Law, the legal system in Hong Kong and the laws relevant to social work practice such as families, workers’ rights, and criminal justice, etc. Discussion will focus on the application of social work values and ethics in contexts, values and ethical dilemmas, as well as the legal implications on social work practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc in Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
- Nature of Social Work
- Historical development & Professionalization of social work
- Definition of social work: Purpose, function and roles of social work
- Legal System
- Laws Relating to Juvenile
- Laws Relating to Family
- Laws Relating to Human Rights
- Philosophical base and core values of social work
- Anti-oppressive practice and Ethical misconduct
- Ethical decision making framework

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Policy and Social Welfare in Hong Kong and East Asia

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: The course aims at helping students to understand the nature, features, development, dilemmas and future prospects of social policy and social welfare in Hong Kong and East Asia. It looks at whether and how far social policy and social welfare in East Asia are different from those of the Western welfare states in terms of role and functions of state and society in the arrangement of welfare, culture and social values, policy instruments, and outcome measures. The social welfare systems in East Asia, in particular with that of Hong Kong in comparison with the rest will be highlighted. The students will be benefited from the comparative perspective for an understanding of the specific context where social policy in Hong Kong and East Asia has developed and the challenges it now faces amidst growing social disparities and economic globalization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Social Policy.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, students are able to understand the basic features of social policy and welfare systems in Hong Kong and East Asia and their underlying dynamics of development and challenges. They are able to practise the skills of reviewing literature and policy documents, classifying and diagnosing problems and issues, and undertaking secondary data analysis, and assessing social policy and welfare systems of Hong Kong and East Asia. Moreover, students are able to refer to ethical judgement on the social settlements which social policy and welfare systems are important components.
courses.course_syllabus:
- An introduction to the concepts of public welfare, welfare states, and social work, human needs, and different perspectives of social welfare
- An introduction to the concepts, definitions, philosophy, professional values and practices of social work; the relationship between social work and social policy
- An overview of social policy and welfare systems in East Asia, understand the social values of Confucian welfare relating to the development of social policy
- Comparative approaches of social policy, East Asia welfare systems in comparative perspective
- Hong Kong: the development of welfare system, its basic features and social policy issues and approaches
- Japan: the development of the welfare state system, personal social services, welfare-state regime
- Taiwan: The transformation of authoritarian, social insurance and corporatist welfare states; developmentalism and democratization, demographic challenges and globalization
- South Korea: Social welfare policy: past and future development, changes in social welfare policies
- Macau: The development of social welfare system, its basic features and social policy issues and approaches
- Singapore: Developmentalism, corporatism, capital-investment state, asset-based social policy, whither welfare state
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Human Behaviour and the Social Environment

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: The course aims to enable students to understand human growth and behaviour throughout the entire life-span from pregnancy to death within different socio-cultural contexts, including family, group, organization and community settings. The basic concepts, theories, and research findings on human growth and behaviour will be introduced. Particular attention will be given to the application of related knowledge to social work practice. The course serves to introduce students to the physical, psychological and socio-cultural aspects of human growth and behaviour and the mutual influences among individuals, families, groups, and the environment. Developmental issues and problems with reference to the different life stages will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able:
1. To critically review the various biopsychosocial theories and perspectives which recognize the interaction between human behavior and the social environment.
2. To demonstrate knowledge of human growth and behavior throughout the life span from pregnancy to death.
3. To demonstrate understanding of the influence of interactions among individuals as well as the interaction between individuals and families, groups, organizations, communities, institutions, and larger systems.
4. To critically assess human developmental needs, problems and hazards in different life stages with relation to social work practice.
5. To apply various biopsychosocial theories and perspectives to explain current social issues in Hong Kong.
6. To demonstrate understanding of the role research plays in generating, supporting, and revising knowledge and the relative gap of evidence across theories and populations.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Understanding human behaviour in the social environment
- An integrative multidimensional framework for assessing current and developmental concerns
- Theoretical perspectives on human development
- Biological, psychological and social development during the following stages:
: pregnancy
: infancy and toddlerhood
: early childhood
: middle childhood
: adolescence
: early adulthood
: middle adulthood
: late adulthood
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussion with students
- Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire
- External examiner’s report (if applicable)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Organizational Theories for Social Service Agencies
courses.description: This course equips students for social service management functions from an organizational theory perspective. It enhances the students’ ability to analyse and reflect on the key issues in social service management in their social service context by furnishing them with multiple theoretical perspectives of organizational theories and conceptualizations of social service agencies. Supporting the students to face the challenges ahead, this course provides an overview of social service management functions, including service planning, people management, quality management, service monitoring and evaluation as well as accountability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After accomplishing this course, students will be able to:

* Describe the development of organization and organizational theories.
* Identify the nature and characteristics of social service organization and reflect on the implications for social service management.
* Apply different theoretical perspectives to explain and reflect on management practice in social service organization.
* Analyse contemporary challenges in managing social service organizations form multiple theoretical perspectives.
* Provide recommendations for enhancing social service management.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Emergence and evolution of organization and organization theory
2. Organization theory: Multiple perspectives
3. Social service agencies as organizations: Multiple conceptualizations
4. Leadership and people management
5. Strategic service planning
6. Quality management
7. Service evaluation
8. Accountability
courses.feedback_evaluation: Student feedback on this course is highly appreciated. The students are encouraged to make use of the Early Feedback Collection System to share their feedback on this course in the middle of the semester and/or talk to the course instructor as they find appropriate. Course evaluation will be conducted in the second last teaching week.

courses.title: Integrated Social Work Practice I

courses.description: This course is the first of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It helps students to examine the philosophy, values, perspectives and the helping process of integrated social work practice and to acquire the knowledge and basic skills necessary in working with individuals and families. The multidimensional context in which intervention occurs will be emphasized. Selected practice theories and models to guide intervention with individuals and families will be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire up-to-date social work knowledge, and skills ; with
greater ability in critical and independent thinking in case formulation and
assessment of needs, preparing them to have more confidence for fieldwork
placement. Our graduates will identify with the humanistic values and ethics of the
social work profession, have more awareness about the importance of using
innovative means in meeting needs of clients and keep abreast of current social issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Introduction and basic issues
- Defining integrative social work practice
- The social work perspectives and practice principles in social work practices

Part II: Framework for assessment
- Person in environment assessment
- Individual assessment
- Family Assessment

Part III : Goal setting and intervention
- Formulation of intervention goals

Part IV: Selected approaches in social work intervention
- Person-centred approach
- Cognitive –behavioural interventions
- Behavioural therapy and Social skills training
- Psychodynamic approach
- Gestalt therapy
- Crisis Intervention

Part V: Termination and evaluation
- Consolidation and termination
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Integrated Social Work Practice II
courses.description: This course is the second of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It aims to help students to acquire knowledge and skills in social group work and understand the roles and functions of social worker in working with multi-client system. Apart from understanding group dynamics and group process, the application of group work approaches and models with diverse clienteles will be explored. Prerequisite: SOWK5951.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare; Prerequisite: SOWK5951
courses.course_syllabus:
1. An overview of social group work
2. Knowledge base of social group work
3. Conceptual Models in Social Group Work
4. Therapeutic / Change Factors in Social Group Work
5. Ethics, roles and leadership of group worker
6. Group Dynamics
7. Group Development Stages
8. Purposive use of activities and programs
9. Important tasks in different stages of a group
10. Group evaluation
11. Application of group work with diverse clientele Readings
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Mid-term course evaluation
- Final course evaluation

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Integrated Social Work Practice III

meetings.instructor: Dr. AU YEUNG Kwok Wai Eric
Dr. AU YEUNG Kwok Wai Eric
Dr. AU YEUNG Kwok Wai Eric

courses.description: This course is the last of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It aims to develop students’ competence for community-based practice. It stresses the skills, techniques and strategies required to mobilize both people and resources to solve social problems at organizational and community level. It examines values and ethical dilemmas facing professional social workers in organizations, communities and policymaking arenas. The social planning and social reform aspects of social work practice are underscored in seeking change to cope with individual, family, and community problems. Laws concerning petition, public assembly and social action in Hong Kong will be introduced in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare; Prerequisite: SOWK5951
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to learn the followings:
1. Understanding the concept of community and how to assess community needs
2. Knowing different models of and perspectives in community work practices and their application in Hong Kong
3. Acknowledging tactics and strategies in empowering & building up the capacity of the community
4. Appreciating how knowledge be put into practice in the specific social contexts
courses.course_syllabus:
- Understanding Community
- Understanding Community Work
- Community Need Assessment
- Perspectives in Working with Community
- Community Practice I:
: Advocacy
: Social Action
- Community Practice II:
: Policy Planning
: Community Capacity Development
- Community Practice III:
: Empowerment
: Neighbourhood Work
- Community Practice IV:
: Community Needs & Strategy Formation
- Community Practice V:
: Community Group Work & Organisation Development
- Community Practice VI:
: Community Care & Networking
: Social Capital & Networking
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Students are welcome to contact the course instructors directly for feedbacks or enquiries
- A build-in mid-term course evaluation would be conducted by the course instructors for the improvement on course teaching

courses.description: This course is a pre-placement preparation course. It aims to prepare students to make constructive use of field instruction. Laboratory training format is adopted in which experiential and reflective learning are emphasized. The emphases of the course are helping students to reflect on social work values and ethics; understand the meaning and nature of field instruction; get hold of essential communication skills; and acquire basic intervention skills. Students will be facilitated to reflect on their attitudes and styles in helping, and to develop more sensitivity and acceptance towards human nature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction
- Values and ethics
- Briefing on community study project
- Use of written work
- Use of field instruction
- Practicing in local culture and service settings
- Programme evaluation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Students are encouraged to put forth their viewpoints and opinions regarding the course on the Blackboard discussion forum. The lecturer will log on the discussion forum and give feedback to opinions posted by students.
2. An evaluation questionnaire will be distributed to students for collection of opinions for improvement in the middle of the course. The data collected will be shared in the class.
3. An evaluation questionnaire will also be conducted at the end of the course to collect students’ opinions on the course.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Service Management Project I
courses.description: This course expects students to select and investigate one aspect of social service management practice in their employing organizations. The aim of the course is to engage students in critically examining the nature and characteristics of the selected aspect of social service management practice and propose innovative ideas and approaches for policy change and organizational improvement. In the process of conducting this project, students will, under the supervision of the course instructor, have the opportunity to learn research methods and further advance their understanding and integration of knowledge in social service management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MA Programme in Social Service Management, Master of Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
- Defining a Social Service Management Project (SSMP)
- Planning a Research Project and Deciding a Topic
- Research Design: Understanding Methodologies
- Qualitative Research Method: A Case Study Design
- Conceptual framework and Research Questions
- Data Collection
courses.feedback_evaluation:
This course uses the following methods to assess the quality of teaching and learning:
1. Mid-term standard course evaluation
2. Term-end standard course evaluation
3. Comments from Internal and External Reviews

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Macro Social Work Practice: Strategic Planning
courses.description: This course provides students with an opportunity to develop an understanding and appreciation of strategic planning as a dimension of macro social work practice used to promote planned change in communities and organizations pertaining to policies, organizational development, programme directions, service innovation, community problem-solving, and so on. Students will be introduced to the basic concepts and strategies, scopes and emphases, methods and processes, as well as techniques, skills and tools of strategic planning that may be used in human service organizations of diverse settings, clienteles, or auspices. Emphasis will be placed on the design of an action project of strategic planning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. recognize the theoretical orientation of different schools on strategy formulation and examine the pros and cons of various approaches in strategic planning
2. apply methods and skills to formulate the strategic plan of an organization
3. conceptualize and analyze the social welfare scene in Hong Kong from a strategic perspective; and
4. possess the mindset of strategic thinking in performing their professional role as social workers and managers.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Strategic Planning Models
- Strategic Analysis: External Environment, Market and Policies on Social Needs and Issues
- Starting up with Value-Mission-Vision
- Value Propositions and Theory of Change
- Strategic Analysis: Organizational Capacities, Leadership and Teaming
- User Experiences and Participation
- Strategic Partnership and Networking
- Strategic Social Innovation
- Formulating and Assessing Strategic Options, Business Model and Program Portfolio
- Financing, Resources Development and Pitching for Strategic Business Plans
- Implementation and Performance Evaluation for Continuous Strategic Planning
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students
2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Human Resource Development in Social Services
courses.description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in developing human resources in the social welfare field and the social service sector in an effective manner. Issues related to the human resource development process including staff recruitment, selection, deployment, training, performance appraisal, and recruitment will be discussed, and topics on leadership, team-building, staff motivation, and Enhanced Productivity Programmes (EPP) will be examined with practice examples.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
- Clarification of terms: Human Resource Management, Human Resource Development, Social Service, Social Work
- Building up a team
- Four key process of a term
- Current situation of Non-Profit Organization
- The development of social service, Social Work and NPO in Mainland China
- Theoretical framework
- Human resource management in action
- Leadership
- HRM issues of NPO in HK and Mainland China
- Characteristics of HRM in social service
- A sustainable HRM strategy for social service
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Enterprise

meetings.instructor:
Dr. CHAN Kwok Fong Joseph, 
Dr. NG Chui Ha, 
Dr. TSE Sze Hei

Dr. CHAN Kwok Fong Joseph, 
Dr. NG Chui Ha, 
Dr. TSE Sze Hei

courses.description: This course introduces to students the field of social entrepreneurship and the best practices of mission-driven social ventures which aim to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. It also stimulates students to explore how social entrepreneurs can affect policy and facilitate system change. Entrepreneurial solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other large societal issues will be addressed through the sharing of experiences by successful practitioners/funders of social entrepreneurial organizations. The course is valuable to anyone who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through strategic philanthropy and social investing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Development of Social Enterprise
- Defining Social Enterprise
- Key Models of Social Enterprise
- Social Impact Assessment of Social Enterprise
- Overview of Social Entrepreneurship
- Site Visits to Social Enterprises in HK
- Class Discussion of Assigned Readings, Sharing of Site Visits, & Developing a Social Enterprise Business Plan
- Ethical Principles and Concerns
- Opportunity Seeking and Alliance Building
- Risk Management
- Social Marketing
- Group Presentation on Business Plan
courses.feedback_evaluation: Common Department course evaluation exercises
courses.required_readings:

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Groupwork Practice with Families
courses.description: The course examines the theories of group dynamics and groupwork skills in working with different types of families. Focuses will be placed on how to use group as a mutualaid system to facilitate the growth of children, parents and families; alleviate isolation; and achieve problem-solving insight. Attention will be given to the role of group worker and his/her purposeful use of group process and programmes to enable individuals and groups to develop effective knowledge and skills to address their own concerns in different contexts, i.e., parents’ groups, groups for children with behavioural or emotional disturbance, volunteer leadership training groups, skills in working with parent-teacher association, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge concerning key topics of group therapy theory and practice including: group planning, needs assessment, group goals, group composition, group structure, group development, group dynamics, group leadership, therapeutic factors, group programme design, group intervention and group evaluation.
2. Increase sensitivity towards current research findings related to groupwork practices and enhance integration of theory and practice in group applications.
3. Develop practical skills in working with families and family members using group-work intervention and how to deal with practice issues in group process.
4. Enhance ethical awareness and cultural competence in group work practices.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction and overview, Perspectives in working with families in groups; Use of systemic perspective
- Parallel groups with issues related to pre-group assessment, micro and macro group design
- Couple groups
- 5A programme logic model 5B Multiple family group
- Multiple family group
- Interventions: Working with individuals in groups
- Critical Incident model and working with conflicts in groups
- Psychodynamic perspective & working with emotions in groups
- Group stage, Group leadership, Working with emotions in groups
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Family Counselling/Family Education Project

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed
Can, change to Eng if needed
Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: This course aims to develop students’ professional competence by helping them integrate theory with practice. In order to facilitate students’ learning, students have to choose an area of interest in family counselling or family education for in-depth study and analysis. Students are required to critically examine the underlying assumptions and operational application of the selected family education or family counselling topic and discuss innovative approaches for improvement. At the end of the course, students are expected to produce a project report and to present their projects in class for intellectual exchange, experiential review and theoretical integration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Enhanced ability in integrating theory and practice as demonstrated in the final project report
2. Increased sensitivity towards cultural, systemic and gender issues in family counselling and family education practice
3. Showed competence in conducting a small scale qualitative/quantitative study or writing a quality group/family education programme proposal
courses.course_syllabus:
• Expectations of the project
• Perspectives in doing the project
• How to do the library search and literature review
• Preparation of Project notes
• What is qualitative research?
• Ethics, validity and reliability
• How to formulate research questions
• Sharing of Exemplar Studies illustrating how to conduct qualitative studies and in-depth interview
• Use of qualitative studies in conducting the family education and family counselling project
• Basic understanding about definitions on “integration” and “integration of theory and practice”
• How to write a project brief
• How to write a project report
• Presentation requirements, cover page, table of contents
• Proper use of quotations and style of references
• Plagiarism: Areas of Attention
• Sharing of Exemplar qualitative studies with emphasis on coding and analysis
• Coding and analysis of interview data
• Thematic analysis

They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Policy Research I
courses.description: Knowledge of fundamental social policy research skills is very important for modern social policy practitioners. Such knowledge increases social policy practitioners’ ability to understand and utilize research findings to inform and enhance their practice and provide the skills necessary to plan and carry out research related to social policy practice. Social policy practitioners also need to know how to use exiting knowledge and to assume leadership in expanding knowledge that identifies effective policy and evidence-based intervention program. The purpose of this course is to develop students’ knowledge of general research in social policy level, particularly in quantitative research methods. Emphasis will be placed on the topics related to development of research questions and hypotheses, evidence-based social policy approach, validity and reliability of measurement, research designs, sampling methods, social surveys, and quantitative data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare and MA in Social Policy
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to help students understand the nature and methods of social policy research. Students who successfully complete this course will be expected to be able to:
1. Develop a beginning understanding of the conceptual foundations and methodological tools of quantitative social research and its application to field of social policy.
2. Discuss how research informs social work practice and service delivery, and social welfare policy.
3. Select appropriate quantitative research methods to study a given vulnerable population or policy problem.
4. Locate, understand, critically analyze, and utilize professional social policy research reports and articles.
5. Identify and discuss ethical issues related to research design and the reporting and use of research results.
6. Discuss issues related to sampling, measurement, data collection, and internal and external threats to validity.
7. To increase students’ awareness of how methodological issues being debated, particularly in the filed of social policy.
8. To enhance class participants’ ability to contribute to and strengthen the scientific based of social policy and social work profession.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Development of research questions and hypotheses
- Evidence-based social policy approach
- Validity and reliability of measurement
- Research designs, sampling methods, social surveys, and quantitative data
courses.feedback_evaluation: Common Department course evaluation exercises

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Comparative Social Security Systems
courses.description: This course aims to help students acquire a comparative perspective on social security systems. It will examine the cross-national variations in the characteristics, traditions, major programmes and outcomes of different social security systems. Emphasis will also be placed on the current issues and debates such as the impact of globalization and population ageing, affordability and equity, reform strategies in general as well as specific programmes – social assistance, health care and pensions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare, MSSc in Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA in Social Policy and MA in Social Service Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the completion of this course, students are expected to have:

a. Knowledge and skills of basic comparative policy research for identifying reference materials and understanding need, right and risks of the targets as well as the policy & planning mechanism.
b. Improved critical and creative reading, presentation and writing by their study of the specific social policies in Hong Kong, China or other countries.
c. Values in concerning the livelihood of the deprived and vulnerable groups and prepare to use social security policies and programmes as macro social work practice to improve their livelihood.
courses.course_syllabus:
- What is “social policy”?
- What are the determinants of social policy?
- What is “social security”?
- Comparative social policy analysis
- Evidence-based lesson-learning
- Poverty: Its meaning and measurement.
- The dimensions of poverty
- Social deprivation, social exclusion and their dimensions
- What is inequality? Why does it matter? Causes and remedies
- The design features of social security programs
- “Welfare” (income support/maintenance) programs and their design
- Social insurance programs and their design
- Policy analysis frameworks
- Social security programs in Hong Kong and mainland China
- Select social security programs in Europe, North America, Singapore and Japan: An overview
- The role of the private sector: Occupational pensions in Hong Kong and Australia and their design features

They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Special Topics (I)
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an opportunity to examine some of the current issues and important developments in the social policy field, with the help of concepts and theories in social work and social policy, and in the context of Chinese societies under rapid socioeconomic transformation. For more in-depth understanding of and reflection on the aforementioned areas, a specific topic under the course will be selected for the students to take in their studies.

courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired in-depth knowledge on topics related to current issues and important developments in the social policy field.
courses.course_syllabus:
A specific topic of the following areas will be selected for a specific term:

Social welfare administration

Aging problems and policies

Housing problems and policies

Education problems and policies

Family problems and policies

Youth problems and policies

Other issues and new developments in the social policy field may be added to meet the preferences of the students when this is deemed appropriate.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Policy Dissertation
courses.description: This course requires students to write a dissertation on an approved topic in social policy under faculty guidance. The emphasis of this dissertation is on current social policy and social development issues in China. The dissertation should be on policy analysis or policy implementation, together with social problem description. It should demonstrate linkage between social policy concepts and theories on one side, and actual policy issues on the other. It may also draw on students’ own practical experience.

• Findings and interpretations/discussions

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Policy Research II

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This course is the second social policy research course. It provides students with basic concepts of qualitative research methods and their application in social policy research. This course will enhance the analytical ability of students to identify the relevant research methods and their strengths and weaknesses in doing social policy research. Specific topics include: qualitative policy research, descriptive qualitative analysis, methods of research design, case study research, field research and research ethics. The research process such as formulation of research question in relation to public policies, theoretical sampling, qualitative data collection and analysis, and methods for secondary analysis and comparative approach will also be emphasized. This course will also examine the uses of qualitative methods for policy reviews and evaluation purposes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MA Programme in Social Policy, MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education, Master of Social Science Programme in Social Work and Master of Social Work Programme
courses.course_syllabus:
- Qualitative policy research
- Descriptive qualitative analysis
- Methods of research design
- Case study research
- Field research
- Research ethics
- Research process such as formulation of research question in relation to public policies, theoretical sampling, qualitative data collection and analysis
- Methods for secondary analysis and comparative approach
- Uses of qualitative methods for policy reviews and evaluation purposes
courses.feedback_evaluation: Common Department course evaluation exercises

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Applied Statistics for Social Work and Social Welfare
courses.description: The course is designed to introduce advanced statistical methods that are used in data analysis and social work research. Both statistical theories and inference techniques will be covered. This is an applied Statistics course for Social Work and Social Welfare, with focuses on statistical theories, probability distributions, bivariate and multivariate analysis. SPSS, a statistical analysis software package, will be used to provide students with knowledge and skills necessary to conduct quantitative social work research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:
1. Understand the theories of statistical inferences and apply the appropriate models in different settings to answer research questions in social work;
2. Master skills in conducting the statistical analyses of data using SPSS.
3. Master skills that will enable them to interpret and document SPSS output and report results in a scholarly manner.
4. Conduct multivariate statistical analyses and extend the analyses methods to social work research practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course includes different techniques in statistical inference, particularly in multivariate analysis, with the discussion of theories for students to evaluate the plausibility of the assumptions in the inference process.

Main topics include:
# Apply T-TEST for Social Work and Social Welfare
• Single sample T-Test
• Two sample T-Tests
# Apply Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) for Social Work and Social Welfare
• One-way ANOVA
• Two-way and multiple-way ANOVA
• ANCOVA
# Apply Correlation and Regression for Social Work and Social Welfare
• Simple Regression
• Multiple Regression
• Logistic Regression
# Non-parametric tests
# Apply Factor Analyses & Path Analyses for Social Work and Social Welfare
• Exploratory Factor Analyses
• Confirmatory Factor Analyses
• Validity and reliability issues
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Students’ responses during classes

• Mid-term course evaluation
• Formal course evaluation at the end of course
• Reflection of teacher

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Digital Transformation in Social Services
courses.description:
To address the digital transformation challenges faced by social services agencies, alignment of ICT strategy with organisation reality across all levels involves the development of a roadmap for ICT adoption and organisation transformation. Practitioners need knowledge and skills to grow their digital competency over time in adapting to the latest digital landscape for delivering more engaging social services.
The purpose of this course is to help students navigate the digital transformation maze through sound program/project management in an evidence-based context. The main goals of digital transformation are needs and competencies assessment, workflow change, and system integration of logic models in supporting data driven decision making. Social service agencies have to put the data in order and equip operation staff with the needed knowledge and skills to function effectively and efficiently.
Use of design thinking and lean startup approach will be integrated into digital social services development and implementation as covered in this course. Furthermore, students will learn to use no-code/low-code digital tools to implement a fully integrated data driven information management and service system. The completed system can be used for ongoing data collection, statistical analysis, and data visualisation for event promotion, service program tracking, volunteer recruitment, impact evaluation, donation accounting, and funding application.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Programmes allowed to enrol: MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy, MA Social Service Management, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work and MPhil-PhD Social Welfare.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students will be able to:

1) Understand the current digital landscape and disruptions facing social services agencies.

2) Assess digital application needs using an integrated design thinking and lean startup approach for managing transformation projects and making sustainable and scalable impacts.

3) Write up application requirement specifications for fostering innovative design and prototype development of a data driven information management and service system.

4) Utilise no-code/low-code digital workflow tools to implement an integrated database system for further stakeholder validation and program evaluation.

5) Collect data and device relevant statistical measures for further data analysis and visualisation with impact assessment and funding application consideration.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Module 1 - Understanding the Digital Transformation Landscape**

* Overview of the disruptive changes to our lives and works caused by the rapidly changing digital landscape with constant innovation found in artificial intelligence/robotics, blockchain, cloud computing/IoT, big data, and immersive technologies.
* Describe how performing data aggregation and data management with digital technologies has become a critical organisational competency for developing an evidence based practice.
* Describe the digital transformation challenges for building the new competency and the implications for social service agencies.

* *Module 2 - Social Innovation with the Lean Startup Methods**

* Overview of the Theory of Change and social innovation at the BOP (Bottom of the Pyramid).
* Introduce the Lean Startup method and how it has been used to build innovative social products and services with a sustainable and scalable social business model.
* Describe the use of low-code/no-code digital tools for performing needs assessment, intervention planning, programme tracking, and impact evaluation.

* *Module 3 - Introduction to Relational Database using Airtable**

* Define the basic structure and process of constructing a relational database.
* Describe the use of Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) for planning a relational database project.
* Introduce Airtable for implementing a relational database.

* *Module 4 - Program Management with Data Analytics in Airtable**

* Demonstrate the use of Airtable for programme planning and tracking.
* Describe the use of Airtable automation features for streamlining work flow and Airtable interface features for enhancing presentation and reporting.
* Introduce the collaboration features in Airtable for team recruitment and coordination.

* *Module 5 - Design Thinking for Needs Assessment**

* Introduce the Design Thinking process and tools.
* Describe how Design Thinking can be combined with Lean Startup methods to perform need assessment, service intervention, and programme evaluation in the context of a logic model.
* Use of low-fidelity prototype (e.g. wireframes and paper prototype) in user testing.

* *Module 6 - Requirement Specification and Wireframe Prototype**

* Describe the use of story map, entity relationship diagrams, site map, and wireframes for specifying application requirements.
* Describe the flow of data through the application — from story map to wireframes, wireframes to database.
* Develop acceptance criteria for validation and quality control.

* *Module 7 - Web Development in WordPress**

* Introduce the Wordpress content management system and how it can be used for scheduling, donation management, training, volunteers recruitment, case management, e-commerce, service subscription, survey, and services tracking through installation of 3rd party plugins.
* Develop customised data tables for special project data entry, data tracking and reporting.
* Secure Wordpress system operation with user right and access management, scheduled backup, and firewall protection.

* *Module 8 - Workflow Integration through Webhooks and Application Program Interface (API)**

* Introduce the use of REST (**Re**presentational **S**tate **T**ransfer) API for common data exchange between different applications and systems.
* Integrate WordPress and Airtable through web hooks and REST API for shared functions and streamlining operations.
* Describe the importance of API in the formation of digital platforms and business models.

* *Module 9 - System Testing and Documentation**

* Prepare test data for user acceptance testing and validation.
* Prepare test result analysis and recommendations.
* Development of documentation for users and support staff for training and operational use.

* *Module 10 - Usability and A/B Testing**

* Introduce the usability test plan for conducting qualitative user research.
* Introduce A/B test for conducting quantitative user research.
* Combine qualitative and quantitative research results for informing application development.

* *Module 11 - Program Evaluation and Logic Models Integration**

* Describe how data gathered through Airtable, WordPress and other digital tools can be integrated to inform program evaluation and logic models integration.
* Use of data analytics tools in website traffic tracking for evidence-based reporting.
* Use of Airtable and Wordpress data for final report write-up and executive presentation.

* *Module 12 - Data Analytics and Data Visualisation for Executive Presentation**

* Describe how to aggregate and summarise data for effective story telling and presentation.
* Introduce data encoding principles for developing data visualisation strategy and chart selection.
* Use of data visualisation features in Airtable and WordPress for executive presentation.

* *Module 13 - Final Presentation**

courses.title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Special Topics (II)

courses.description: This course is designed in response to changing needs of families in view of the rapid social changes and transformation in family functions and structures. This course aims to provide students with an opportunity of acquiring updated and advanced clinical skills and theories on family interventions. Other issues and new developments related to family education and family counselling may be added to meet the training needs of the students.

- grasp different theoretical perspectives of counseling
- students’ practice skills in counseling will be enhanced

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Structural Family Therapy

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description: This course examines the underlying philosophical assumptions, the major theoretical constructs and the application of structural family therapy in Hong Kong. Students will be helped to develop professional competence in working with different types of families in need and to be self-reflexive of their own personal style in helping. A critical review of structural family therapy especially in addressing the gender issue and the socio-cultural differences of different societies will be made.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, it is expected that students would be able to:
1. Critically examine the shift in perspective from modernism to postmodernism and its implications for family assessment and intervention
2. Acquire a systems perspective in conceptualizing the family in need
3. Recognize the contributions and constraints of structural family therapy in family assessment and intervention in different social service settings
4. Heighten their sensitivity and awareness in ethical, cultural and gender issues as well as the use of self in family assessment and intervention; and
5. Link up the importance of larger social systems intervention with family therapy in helping.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Revisit systems perspective, modernist and post-modernist’s views on family therapy
- Critical review of systems theory—feminist’s and cultural lens in the era of globalization
- Ethical issues related to couple and family therapy: using family violence as an illustration
- Structural family therapy (SFT) in dialogue with other family therapy approaches—An integrative approach and larger systems collaboration
- The four steps model of assessment: working with couples
- The four-steps model of assessment: working with families of children with mental health needs (e.g., children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; Autism Spectrum Disorder)
- The four steps model of assessment: working with families of adolescents with mental health needs
- Clinical observation
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Marital Therapy
courses.description: This course aims to help students understand different approaches in working with couples with marital distress. It examines the underlying philosophical assumptions, the major theoretical constructs and the application of marital therapy in Hong Kong. It also aims to enhance knowledge and skills of students in dealing with marital impasse and working with emotional reactivity of couples. Apart from helping students integrate the theoretical concepts of marital therapy in practice, the course also helps students develop competence in working with couples and cultivate their personal style of helping. Focuses will be lay on the application of marital therapy in working with couples with various concerns such as extra marital affairs, issues of family origin, or one party suffering from depression.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc in Social Work and MA in Family Counselling & Family Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student should:
- Develop critical reflection upon societal and their own values on marriage
- Be able to beware how the above mentioned values affect their clinical intervention
- Be able to grasp different theoretical perspectives of marital counseling
- Develop practice skills in marital counseling
courses.course_syllabus:
* Modern dilemma of intimate relationship
* Ethical Concerns of marital counselors
* Development of marital counseling
* Conceptual framework of marital counseling
* Inner world of a partner in an intimate relationship
* Patterns of couple dynamics
* Process of marital counseling
* Skills of marital counseling
* Patterns of marital infidelity
* Forgiveness and reconciliation after the crisis of marital infidelity
* Uncoupling and Divorce process
* Post-divorce counseling
courses.feedback_evaluation:
A mid-term evaluation will be conducted in approximately the 6th or 7th teaching week. Students are encouraged to give feedback in this evaluation so as to improve the learning experience in the second half of the semester.
Course evaluation will be conducted in the second last teaching week.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Professional Ethics and Legal Issues in Marriage and Family Therapy
courses.description: This course will study the ethical and legal issues in marriage and family therapy in various international and local contexts. The course aims at helping students to acquire knowledge about important ethical and legal issues in practice as a marriage and family therapist. The multicultural competence of students will be fostered to enable them to work with people in diversity. Students will be helped to reflect on their personal values and to show commitment to professional values in practice of marriage and family therapy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

The following topics will be covered:
1. The American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy (AAMFT) Code of Ethics
2. Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance
3. Ethical dilemma in practice.
4. Self-evaluation on personal and professional values in practicing marriage and family therapy
5. Managing difficult cases with suicide, violence, addiction and abuse
6. Practice with human diversity: socioeconomic status
7. Practice with human diversity: ethnicity
8. Practice with human diversity: religion
9. Practice with human diversity: gender
10. Practice with human diversity: sexual orientation
11. Legal knowledge, legal responsibility and liability concerning practice of marriage and family therapy.
12. Continuing professional development

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Practical Skills in Marriage and Family Therapy
courses.description: This course equips students with the essential skills and techniques in clinical assessment and diagnosis; treatment planning and case management; and therapeutic interventions in marriage and family therapy. Special attention will be given to the integrative use of relevant models and theories as well as the adoption of cultural and gender perspective in practice. The course is valuable to helping professionals who want to acquire core competencies in couples and family work.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Arts Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education (Specialization: Accredited Programme on Marriage and Family Therapy) only
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

The following topics will be covered:

- Present trend and development of the theories, the models and the research findings of the marriage and family therapy disciplines;
- Essential skills in intake and engagement (e.g., determine who should attend therapy; establish appropriate and productive therapeutic alliance with family)

- Essential skills in clinical assessment and diagnosis (e.g., apply effective and systemic interviewing and observational techniques and strategies; identify family strengths, resilience and resources)

- Family assessment instruments review, reliability and validity

- Core techniques in treatment planning and case management (e.g., involve family in the process of treatment plan; work collaboratively with different stakeholders, family members and other significant persons and professionals not present)

- Core competencies in therapeutic interventions (e.g., reframing, recurving interaction patterns, generating relational questions and reflexive comments)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Clinical Internship in Marriage and Family Therapy I
courses.description: This course provides an opportunity for students to learn marriage and family therapy through clinical practice with individuals, couples and families. Students are required to have internship in community agencies or public institutions under clinical supervision of an approved supervisor. The course focuses on the development of basic assessment skills, integration of theories into practice, and personal and professional growth of students. The major goal of the internship is for the preparation of students to practice marriage and family therapy for individuals, couples and families in different social services, healthcare and educational settings upon graduation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Arts Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education (Specialization: Accredited Programme on Marriage and Family Therapy) only
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:
- engage with client system
conduct assessment formulate treatment planning
- carry out interventions and case management
- assess treatment and clinical outcome
- commit to professional ethics and legal requirements in the practice
- appraise their own strengths and limitations and promote personal and professional growth and development
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)
Students must obtain at least 125 hours of clinical practice in clinical internship, including:
- At least 62 hours of face-to-face client contact with relational cases- couple or families. The remaining 63 hours could be relational or individual cases.
- At least 50 hours of supervision (individual and group) of those cases
- At least 12 cases must be directly observed (live or videotaped). During the internship experience, students will be given the opportunities to observe direct practice of other family therapists.

The following topics will be covered:
- Establishment of therapeutic Contact with Client System
- Client Assessment Treatment Planning
- Therapeutic interventions and Case Management
- Assessment of treatment and clinical outcome
- Documentation
- Commitment to professional ethics and legal requirements in the practice
- Ability to evaluate their own strengths and limitations and promote personal and professional growth and development.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Mid-term course evaluation
- Final course evaluation
