courses.description: The course provides opportunities for students to put theories into practice. Students will be placed in a social service setting for supervised practice. Through exposure to reallife situations and a refl ective learning process, the course aims to help students to apply principles and methods of social work intervention in practice, to make differential use of community resources, to function effectively in organizational context, to develop their professional qualities and competence, and then to become an independent professional social worker.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work; Prerequisite: SOWK5951, SOWK5952, SOWK5953 and SOWK5955
courses.course_syllabus:
To be eligible for registration as a Registered Social Worker, students are required to undertake a total of not less than 900 hours of fieldwork which includes:
1. 100 hours of pre-placement preparation training sessions (compulsory attendance), and
2. Two field placements each achieving not less than 400 hours supervised practice during the course of study

Each student will be placed in two different service settings in different social welfare service agencies to fulfil the requirement for supervised practice. Non-local field placement is also offered in order to help students develop an international perspective and world vision. Apart from direct social work practice, relevant agency visits, community visits and participation in agency staff conferences are also encouraged in the field placement to enable students to become familiar with their field of service and enlarge their practice experiences.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Final course evaluation
courses.required_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.
courses.recommended_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Youth Culture and Youth Work
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an in-depth understanding of youth culture and youth work in global and local contexts. It explores different concepts of youth and their theoretical and ideological foundations, and discusses key themes in studies of youth culture including youth in society (e.g. citizenship, school-to-work transition, social inclusion and exclusion), youth cultural practice (e.g. subcultures, globalization, consumption and identity), and youth in community (e.g. democratic participation, youth and public space). The course furthermore examines approaches to youth work in contemporary societies, with emphases on reflective understanding of the problems and needs of today’s youth, and critical appraisal of major youth work models. Current policy issues related to human rights and well-being of young people will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work, and Master of Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:
1) Have an in-depth understanding of youth culture and youth work in global and local contexts
2) Understand different concepts of youth and their theoretical and ideological foundations
3) Understand various approaches to youth work in contemporary societies
4) Acquire knowledge on current policy issues related to human rights and well-being of young people
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I. Foundation of Youth and Youth Development
- Overview of Course and Defining Youth
- Theoretical Foundation of Youth and Youth Development
- Biological and Cognitive Development
- Context Matters I: Family/School/Peers
- Context Matters II: Youth Cultural Practice

Part II. Principles of Youth Work/Program
- Youth Work Models/ Evidence-based youth work
- Youth Services in Hong Kong
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students
2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire
courses.required_readings:
Furlong, A. (2016). Routledge handbook of youth and young adulthood. London, Taylor and Francis.

Hall, S. and T. Jefferson (2006). Resistance Through Rituals : Youth Subcultures in Post-War Britain. Oxford, UK, Taylor & Francis Group.

Hartung, P. J. (2015). The Career Construction Interview. Career Assessment: Qualitative Approaches. M. McMahon and M. Watson. Rotterdam, SensePublishers: 115-121.

Savickas, M. L. (2015). Life-Design Counseling Manual

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Family Intervention
courses.description: This course aims to help students acquire knowledge and skills in working with families. Specifically, it attempts to familiarize students with current major approaches in working with families, to acquire knowledge in family assessment and intervention, and to develop an integrative perspective in family practice. The implications of social changes on family, the changing family ideologies, gender issue in family, policies on family and the adequacy of family services will be critically examined with particular reference to the Hong Kong context.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to:
1. Understand the theoretical foundation, basic concepts and skills of major approaches in working with families that have been taught in the course.
2. Demonstrate understanding of knowledge in family assessment and intervention.
3. Develop an integrative perspective on family practice.
4. Critically examine the structural, ideological, and cultural issues in family interventions in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Family-centered practice: The guiding framework of family intervention
- Structural family interventions
- Narrative family interventions and collective practice
- Groupwork in Family intervention: Multiple family group/therapy
- Exo- and Macro-level intervention of Family-centered Practice
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.
courses.required_readings:
Lau, Y. K. (2011). A narrative oriented multiple-family group with students who refused to attend school and their parents. International Journal of Narrative Therapy and Community Work, 2011(4), 46-57. <https://doi.org/10.1080/08865710802209594>

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Cognitive-behavioural Intervention
courses.description: The course aims to examine human psychosocial problems from a cognitive-behavioural perspective. The reciprocal interaction among human cognition, behaviour and environment will be highlighted. The major schools of cognitive-behavioural therapies will be introduced and their applications in helping individuals and families will be covered. Application issues such as alliance building, homework compliance and adaptation of cognitive-behavioural intervention in local context will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Social Science in Social Work and Master of Arts in Family Counselling and Family Education Programs
courses.course_syllabus:
- CBI Overview
- Frameworks of Case Conceptualization in CBI
- Self-Instructional Training and REBT
- Beck’s Cognitive Therapy
- Application of CBI: Anxiety and panic disorder
- Third Wave of CBT
- Strengths-based CBT
- Strategies and Skills Learning and Development (SSLD)
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course instructor will collect feedback from students half way through the course, for enhancement of course content and delivery in accordance to students’ learning needs. Students can also talk to the course instructor on their learning experience and find the course instructor for academic discussion whenever necessary.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Solution-focused Approach
courses.description: This course examines the solution-focused approach within the family system framework and post-modern perspective. It helps students understand the basic assumptions and theoretical foundations of the approach, and gives specific principle for intervention. Apart from helping students integrate the theoretical concepts of solution-focused therapy in practice, the course also aims to help students develop professional competence and to expand their personal style of helping. Special attention will be paid to address the gender and class issues and the differential use of solution-focused therapy in the cultural context of Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Students of Master of Social Science in Social Work and Master of Arts in Family Counselling and Family Education students
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction & overview on Solution-focused therapy

- Paradigm shift, theoretical perspectives and historical roots

- Basic of solution focused, goal setting

- Client engagement and worker client relationship

- The process of change and useful questions

- Solution-focused group
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students

2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Clinical Social Work Practice: Selected Approaches– Marriage & Family Therapy
courses.description: This course aims to provide an extensive review of the theoretical foundations of the various schools of marriage and family therapy, from modernism to post-modernism. The focus will be on unifying conceptual threads that integrate different approaches, including Bowenian, strategic, structural, experiential, solution-focused, and narrative. Techniques from various models that are applicable to family therapy with Chinese families will also be addressed. The teaching format includes lecture, videotaped segments of family interviews, role-play, and case discussion.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Evolution of family therapy

2. Classic schools of family therapy

3. Postmodernism

4. Fundamental concepts of family therapy

5. Family assessment with children

6. Family assessment with adolescent

7. Working with couples

8. Working with larger systems

9. Family interviewing skills
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work with People with Disabilities
courses.description: Social workers who work with people with disabilities (PWDs) nowadays should have critical mind and self-reflective attitudes to meet the challenges from the changing field of disabilities. To enhance the quality of life of PWDs, social workers should have sensitivity to understand situations of individuals with disabilities, and have substantial knowledge of intervening in different levels of environments. Providing students an insightful learning process, this course uses interactive and experiential activities besides traditional one-way lectures. Guests, including person(s) with intellectual disabilities, person(s) with physical disabilities, their carers, and social workers, will be invited to share their life experience in class. This course introduces students to the paradigm shift in the international disability field, the evolution of services affecting PWDs, and contemporary approaches to provide services to PWDs.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

The following topics will be covered:

1. What is Disability
2. Paradigm Shift and Models of Disability
3. Different Kinds of Disabilities and Their Characteristics
4. Disability Sensitivity and Tips for Interacting with PWDs
5. The Persons (PWDs)
5. 1 Lives, Life Map and Dreams
5. 2 Main Issues: Quality of Life & Self-Determination
5. 3 Intervention Approaches
6. Microsystem
6. 1 Families and Carers of PWDs
6. 2 Overview of Rehabilitation Services & Trends for Service Development
6. 3 Empowerment & Advocacy
7. Mesosystem
7. 1 Interface between Microsystems
7. 2 Roles of Social Worker in Midlevel Intervention
8. Exosystem and Macrosystem
8. 1 Universal Design (Access, transport and information communication technology)
8. 2 Legislation and Policy
8. 3 Culture and Societal Value
8. 4 Macrolevel Intervention
9. Conclusion
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Students’ responses during classes
- Informal interaction with students
- Formal course evaluation at end of course
- Reflection of teacher

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Service Planning, Programme Development and Evaluation
courses.description: This course is crafted to equip students with an advanced understanding of social service management in terms of service planning, programme development and evaluation. It first prepares the students to analyse and reflect on the nature and characteristics of social service followed by grounding in social service value frameworks to address the purposes and functions of social service management. Further, it furnishes the students with essential theoretical knowledge and practice approaches for enhancing their capacity in social service management, including service and programme planning, resources management, quality management, programme monitoring and evaluation, as well as accountability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare and MSSc in Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

i. Describe the nature and characteristics of social service and reflect on their implications for social service management.

ii. Apply the value frameworks to address critical issues in social service management.

iIi. Inform different theoretical perspectives of and practice approaches to social service management.

iv. Appraise advantages and limitations of different theoretical perspectives and practice approaches.

v. Provide recommendation(s) for enhancing social service management.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Nature and characteristics of social service I
2. Nature and characteristics of social service II
3. Value frameworks: Participatory management in neoliberal and managerial social service context
4. Strategic service planning
5. Programme planning and development logic
6. Programme management
7. Programme monitoring and evaluation
8. Accountability
courses.feedback_evaluation: Student feedback on this course is highly appreciated. The students are encouraged to make use of the Early Feedback Collection System to share their feedback on this course in the middle of the semester and/or talk to the course instructor as they find appropriate. Course evalution will be conducted in the second last teaching week.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Master of Social Science Project
courses.description: The course requires students to write an individual project paper related to their field practicum. The paper aims to engage students in critically examination of practice theories and skills concerning needs and characteristics of target groups, goals of intervention, and programme design. In the process of writing the paper, students are required to apply knowledge of social work research in practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Rationale for the project
3. Problem / need definition and characteristics of the clientele
4. Goals, objectives and strategies of intervention
5. Evaluation
6. Reflections
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.
courses.required_readings:
- Corey, G. (2013). *Theories and Practice of Counselling and Psychotherapy*, (9th Ed.) Belmont, CA. : Brooks/Cole.

- Fox, M., Martin, P., & Green, G. (2007). *Doing Practitioner Research*. London: Sage (Chapter 9: Writing the research report).

- Royse, D., Thyer, B.A., & Padgett, D.K. (2010). *Program Evaluation – An introduction*. Belmont, CA: Wadsworth. (Ch. 15: Writing

evaluation proposals, reports, and Journal articles)

- Rubin, A., & babble, E. (2011). *Research Method for Social Work*. Belmont, CA: Brooks/Cole. (Ch 2: Evidence-based practice).

- 林孟平 (2015)***。輔導與心理治療***。香港：商務印書館。

- 羅國英、張紉(譯)(2007) 。***方案評估：方法及案例討論***。台北：雙葉。

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Youth:Risk and Resilience
courses.description: The course examines the differing perspectives of identifying at-risk youth. It aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the at-risk youth in the contexts of peer, family, school and community. With an emphasis on the integration of theory and practice, the course examines different approaches of working with at-risk youth, and analyzes psychological and social intervention strategies that may help in the development of youth resilience. Topical areas of particular relevance to work with youth such as sexuality, non-engaged youth, juvenile delinquency, substance abuse and positive youth development are examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work, MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare and MSSc in Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Linking the concept of resilience to the emerging discourses on youth-at-risk

2. Theoretical foundations of the existential-phenomenological approach to understanding at-risk youth

- Illustration & discussion: Self-harm & suicide

- Illustration & discussion: Youth mental health

3. Process and skills of the existential-phenomenological approach to nurturing resilience in at-risk youth

- Illustration & discussion: Social withdrawal

- Illustration & discussion: Internet addiction

4. Linking the concept of resilience to the emerging discourses on youth-at-risk

- Critical-structuralist approaches

- Hermeneutical-poststructuralist approaches

- Risk & resilience: A cultural appraisal

5. Theoretical foundations of the hermeneutical-poststructuralist approach to understanding at-risk youth

- Illustration & discussion: School dropout

- Illustration & discussion: Substance abuse

6. Process and skills of the hermeneutical-poststructuralist approach to nurturing resilience in at-risk youth

- Illustration & discussion: Sexuality & pregnancy

- Illustration & discussion: Juvenile delinquency

7. Strengthening family resilience

8. Fostering resilience in school and community

9. Integrating the existential-phenomenological and hermeneutical-poststructuralist approaches with the existing youth work models

- Positive youth development model

- Strength-based youth work practice

- Youth empowerment model
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students

- Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire

- External examiner report

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Working with Children & Youth with Special Needs
courses.description: This course examines the nature and needs of children and youth with special needs including various physical disabilities, intellectual disability, specific learning difficulty, autistic spectrum, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. The assessment and interventions of these clients and their families will be introduced and the roles of various professionals working with these young people, especially, the role of social worker, will be examined. Relevant education, policy, medical and legal issues are discussed. It also initiates a critical discussion on the evidence-based practice which is built on up-to-date empirical findings in local context, and the challenge of social work intervention in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education and MA Programme in Social Policy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Models of need assessment for children and youth with special needs
1. 1 Medical model and diagnostic assessment
1. 2 Developmental perspective and life cycle model for assessment
1. 3 Social-ecological model in assessment
1. 4 Social goal model for an enabling environment
1. 5 Towards an integrated approach for assessment

2. Family-based assessment and intervention
2. 1 Childhood disability and family coping
2. 2 System concepts and family assessment
2. 3 Ecological context and family life cycle transition
2. 4 Strength perspective and resilience model in working with the family

3. Early intervention for children with special needs
3. 1 Case management and the trans-disciplinary approach in early intervention
3. 2 Factors influencing effectiveness on early detection and intervention
3. 3 Service models for children with signs of developmental problems
3. 4 Strategies of parental engagement and support

4. Working with adolescents with special needs
4. 1 Developmental perspective in understanding the bio-psycho-social needs of children and youth with special needs
4. 2 Approaches for the enhancement of social and emotional adjustment among adolescents with special needs
4. 3 Service strategies for youth participation and social inclusion

5. Education for children and youth with special needs
5. 1 Philosophy and history of special education and inclusive education
5. 2 Ecological perspective in analysing students’ need in school adjustment
5. 3 Peer relationship and the psycho-social adjustment of students with special needs
5. 4 Role of social worker in school policy advocacy

6. Career plan and vocational training support for youth with special needs
( guest lecture)

7. Social participation and advocacy
7. 1 Rights for citizen participation among person with special needs
7. 2 Public policies and legal rights for person with special needs in Hong Kong
7. 3 Self- help movement among people with special needs
7. 4 Challenges and opportunities ahead for social participation

8. Working with children and youth with autism
8. 1 Assessment and intervention approaches in helping children and youth with autism
8. 2 Challenges concepts and approaches in working with children and youth with autism
8. 3 Helping parents of children with autism: issues related to clinical practice
8. 4 Building up an inclusive environment: shifts in service delivery model

9. Working with children and youth with Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity
9. 1 Understanding ADHD from different perspectives
9. 2 New advances on clinical treatment and family-based intervention
9. 3 Challenges in collaboration among the medical-school-family systems
9. 4 Use of multiple families group in Hong Kong for families with ADHD children

10. Working with children with youth with dyslexia
10. 1 Understanding dyslexia and its impacts onto developmental adjustment
10. 2 Family adaptation in facing the challenges of having a child with dyslexia
10. 3 Service strategies for the support of children and youth with dyslexia
10. 4 Battering against dyslexia: opportunities for diversity

11. Working with children and youth with physical impairment
11. 1 Physical impairment and the rehabilitation process
11. 2 Stress model and this implication of service design in Hong Kong
11. 3 Identity issues among children and youth with physical impairment
11. 4 Existential approach in youth counselling

12. Working with children and youth with hearing impairments
12. 1 Deaf culture and the use of language
12. 2 Support network among person with hearing difficulties
12. 3 Challenges faced by youth with hearing difficulties in mainstream education
12. 4 Inclusive sports for youth with hearing difficulties

13. Working with children and youth with visual impairments
13. 1 Causes for visual impairment and the intervention approaches
13. 2 Challenges faced by families having a child with visual impairment
13. 3 Vocational training and career preparation for youth with visual impairment
13. 4 The era of social innovation and its implication for advocacy

14. Overview on Service Provisions for Children & Youth with Special Needs in Hong Kong
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Use of Arts, Dance and Experiential Learning in Social Work Practice
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding in using different creative media to enhance awareness, instill cognitive changes and facilitate personal growth of clients. The course utilizes the experiential learning theories to equip students with skills and knowledge in using arts, movement and creative media in various social service settings. Critical reflection about cultural implications in practice is emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- To equip students with knowledge about theory and knowledge in using arts, movement, creative media and experiential learning in various social work setting.
- To enable students learning facilitation skills in using arts, movement, creative media and experiential learning in social work practice
- To let the participants have critical reflection about use of art and experiential learning in Chinese cultural context
- To stimulate students using arts, creative media and dance as narratives of representation and creativity, a means of working with clients in social work intervention
courses.course_syllabus:
- Use of Dance in Praxis
- Illustrations of use of art in Praxis
- Photovoice
- Use of photography in Social work practice
- Use of Arts and Dance in Social Work Practice
- Research
- Experiential Learning
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Family-centered Social Work Practice
courses.description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in family-centered practice in social work practice. The underlying assumptions, theoretical concepts and helping principles of family-centered practice for assessment, formation of intervention goals and delineation of intervention strategies are discussed. The roles that social work practitioners play in the delivery of social welfare services in a variety of social work settings such as child protection system, medical and psychiatric settings, foster care, adoption and residential care are also examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work, MA Family Counselling & Family Education
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Family-centered practice

* What is family-centered practice?
* Theoretical framework and basic beliefs

2. Structural family interventions

* Basic concepts of structural family intervention
* The four-step model of assessment and intervention at Micro- and Messo-levels

3. Narrative family interventions and collective practice

* Basic beliefs and concepts of Narrative family interventions
* The intervention strategies of Narrative family interventions
* Bridging the Micro, Messo, Exo and Macro levels interventions through narrative approach.

4. Exo-and Macro-level intervention of family-centered Practice

* Capacity building
* Family support services to prevent and reduce stress and risk
* Building family-centered service systems and practice model
* Advocacy for policy change
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Urban Social Work in Chinese Context
courses.description: This course aims to help students understand the development and current situation of social work in contemporary urban China and fully recognize the opportunity and challenges faced by social work in Chinese cities. The course content will include the pilot and model of social work service in different cities, changes in service delivery and funding, development of innovative social management and NGOs. Mainstream urban social work services on families and children, youth, senior citizens, disabled people and women will be introduced; other services on mobile population, labour and the poor will also be covered in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Factors affecting development of social work in China: The Macro Context

2. Development and Debates of Social Work in China

3. Social Development or Social Control: Government-led Service in Shanghai & Shenzhen

4. Innovation in social management: Experience of development of NGOs and project-based service in Guangzhou

5. Mobile population, peasant workers & labour: Social Movement & social Services

6. Children, Youth & School Social Work: Problem-based/Strength-based/Right-based Perspective

7. Social Work with Women: Empowerment and Disempowerment

8. Social work with Elderly: Community and Home as bases of social care

9. Medical and Rehabilitation Social Work: Multidisciplinary collaboration in secondary setting

10. Social Work with marginal groups: the tension between post-modernist and modernist intervention
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Family-centered Practice in Mental Health Services
courses.description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in family-centered practice for clients suffering from mental health problem and/ or mental disorders. The underlying assumptions, theoretical concepts and helping principles of family-centered practice for assessment, formation of intervention goals and delineation of intervention strategies are discussed. Emphasis is also placed on the discussion of contributions of gender and cultural perspectives in family social work practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare

* *1. Family-centered practice**

* What is family-centered practice?
* Theoretical framework and basic beliefs

* *2.** **Structural family interventions**

* Basic concepts of structural family intervention
* The four-step model of assessment and intervention at Micro- and Messo-levels

* *3.** **Narrative family interventions** **and collective practice**

* Basic beliefs and concepts of Narrative family interventions
* The intervention strategies of Narrative family interventions
* Bridging the Micro, Messo, Exo and Macro levels interventions through narrative approach.

* *4. Exo-and Macro-level intervention of family-centered Practice**

* Capacity building
* Family support services to prevent and reduce stress and risk
* Building family-centered service systems and practice model
* Advocacy for policy change

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Clinical Social Work Practice with Children and Youth with Mental Health Problems
courses.description: This course equips students with different intervention approaches (e.g. client-centered approach, family therapy, group work) in assessing and helping children and youth suffering from mental health problems and/ or mental disorders. It aims to enhance students’ awareness of the importance of evidence-based clinical practice in helping. It also aims to help students develop their model of practice which is contextually based.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work, MA Family Counselling & Family Education
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theoretical perspectives

* Bio-psycho-social perspectives in childhood and adolescent mental health and its implications for assessment and intervention
* Social stigma and psychosocial effects of psychiatric diagnosis on children and adolescents with mental health needs and their families
* Systemic framework in assessment and management
* Family-centered care in children’s and adolescents’ mental health
* Critical socio-cultural issues (e.g., poverty, traditional Chinese cultural beliefs) in assessment and intervention
* Evidence-based clinical practice

2. Family-centered practice for children and adolescents with different mental health needs

* Family-centered practice and childhood and adolescent disorders such as
+ anxiety disorders
+ depression
+ schizophrenia
+ anorexia nervosa and obesity
+ attention deficit and/or hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
+ learning disorder
+ autistic spectrum disorder
+ intellectual disabilities
* Multiple family groups with families of children and adolescents with mental health needs
* Roles and functions of social workers in family-centered care in children’s and adolescents’ mental health, multidisciplinary teamwork in mental health services, social services and the education sector.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

Reupert, A., & Maybery, D. (2007). Families affected by parental mental illness: A multiperspective account of issues and interventions. *American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, 7*(3), 362–369.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Clinical Social Work Practice in Mental Health
courses.description: This course equips students with integrated and holistic approaches in assessing and helping clients suffering from mental health problems and/ or mental disorders. It aims to enhance students’ awareness of the importance of evidence-based clinical practice in helping. It also aims to help students develop their model of practice which is contextually based.
courses.enrollment_requirement: for Master of Social Work (MSW) and Master of Arts (MA) in Family Counselling and Family Education students only
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theoretical perspectives

* Bio-psycho-social perspectives in adult mental health and the implications for assessment and intervention
* Social stigma and psychosocial effects of psychiatric diagnosis on adults with mental health needs and their families
* Systemic framework in assessment and management
* Family-centered care in adults’ mental health
* Evidence-based clinical practice

2. Family-centered practice for adults with different mental health problems

* Family therapy and adult mental health problems such as
+ Schizophrenia
+ Depression
+ Anxiety Disorder
* Empowerment of families and the family member(s) to cope with mental illness
* Roles and functions of social workers in working with adult clients with mental health problems in a family context
* Systems collaboration and multidisciplinary teamwork among several institutions

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Social Work Research
courses.description: This course helps students understand the relationship between social research and social work practice. The basic concepts, approaches, methods and issues in qualitative and quantitative research will be introduced. The course will address the process of formulating research questions and hypotheses, methods of data collection, data analyses, and social work research ethics. Students will examine research methods associated with policy practice, clinical intervention and ethical issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc in Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to help students understand the nature and methods of social work research. Students who successfully complete this course will be expected to be able to:
1. Develop a beginning understanding of the conceptual foundations and methodological tools of quantitative and qualitative social research and its application to field of social work.
2. Discuss how research informs social work practice and service delivery, and social welfare policy.
3. Select appropriate quantitative and/or qualitative research methods to study a given vulnerable population or social problem.
4. Locate, understand, critically analyze, and utilize professional social work research reports and articles.
5. Identify and discuss ethical issues related to research design and the reporting and use of research results.
6. Discuss issues related to sampling, measurement, data collection, and internal and external threats to validity.
7. To increase students’ awareness of how methodological issues being debated, particularly in the filed of social work practice.
8. To enhance class participants’ ability to contribute to and strengthen the scientific based of social work profession.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course introduction, overview, and scientific inquiry

2. Problem formation, literature review, & ethics

3. Conceptualization, operationalization
Measurement
Constructing questions

4. Causal inference
Research designs: pre-experimental & experimental

5. Sampling and survey research

6. Quantitative data analysis (1)
- Descriptive statistics
- Difference test (t-test, ANOVA)

7. Quantitative data analysis(2)
- Association test (chi-square and correlation)
- Linear regression

8. Qualitative Research
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course instructor will collect feedback from students half way through the course, for enhancement of course content and delivery in accordance to students’ learning needs. Students can also talk to the course instructor on their learning experience and find the course instructor for academic discussion whenever necessary.
courses.required_readings:
Bryman, A. (2012). Social Research Methods (4th ed.). New York: Oxford University Press. Chapter 3

Kim, M. (2022). Exploring factors influencing social workers’ attitudes toward evidence- based practice: A Chinese study. International Social Work, 65(5), 912–926.

Rubin, A. & Babbie, E. (2024). Research Methods for Social Work (10th ed.). Cengage Learning.

(Detailed references will be provided in the Course Outline of the respective academic year.)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Master of Social Work Project
courses.description: This course aims to facilitate students’ professional competence by helping them integrate theory and practice. Students are required to choose an area of interest in their specific concentration for in-depth study and analysis. Students have to critically examine the needs and characteristics of the target groups, the influential social ideologies, related social policies, critical contextual factors and the interconnection of these elements in affecting the well-being of individual and family. In the process of the project, students also have the opportunity to further integrate their knowledge of social work research and practice. According to the results of the study, students have to discuss innovative approaches for improvement or innovative service models in their project reports. In order to facilitate learning, students will be arranged in small groups.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Session** | **Content** |
| --- | --- |
| 1 | * Introduction and overview * Guidelines for individual project report * How to identify knowledge gap, formulate research question and chooseconceptual framework through literature review |
| 2-3 | * Meet with the instructor individually or in small group |
| 4-5 | * Presentation of project brief |
| 6 | * Individual or group consultations based on the submitted project brief |
| 7 | * Group consultation and supervision related to progress of the project and special issues |
| 8 | * Group consultation and supervision on the implementation of research and data analyses |
| 9-14 | * Student presentations |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are invited to complete a term-end evaluation to improve the content and teaching quality of the course. They are also welcome to participate in the Annual Staff-Student Consultative Meeting (ASSCM) to provide comments and suggestions for the Programme and course instructors. Students can also send emails to the course instructor for exchanging ideas or providing feedback.

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Use of Information and Communication Technology in Social Services

meetings.instructor:
Mr WONG Kon Chi, 
Mr. HO Chun Yu

courses.description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in utilizing information and communication technologies (ICTs) to develop, operate, manage, and evaluate social services. The course will focus on the non-profit organizations and public administration contexts to teach and discuss how ICTs can be innovatively applied for social good, and how we can harness the new technologies to ensure their usage to be ethical and sustainable. No previous training in ICTs or computer science is required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
1. Identify the information needs in providing social services, and discuss how ICT can improve the decision making process in social work practice at various levels.
2. Make proposal of ICT development project following relevant principles and processes
3. Identify and critically discuss the impacts of ICT development in society and social service provision.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Course introduction & overview

- Brief history of ICT and current use in social services

- Needs assessment, design thinking, and ICT project development

- ICT project management & evaluation

- Bio-psycho-social issues associating with ICT use

- Website

- Online forums and social media

- Instant messaging

- Mobile Apps and Games

- Internet of things

- Big data and artificial intelligence
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students
- Final evaluation by means of standard course evaluation questionnaire
- External examiner’s report (if applicable)
- Students are welcome to talk to the course instructor on their learning experience whenever
necessary.
courses.required_readings:
Watling, S., & Rogers, J. (2012). Social work in a digital society. London: California: Learning Matters ; SAGE Publications.

Hill, A., & Shaw, I. (2011). Social work & ICT. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications Inc.

López Peláez, A., & Kirwan, G. (Eds.). (2023). The Routledge international handbook of digital social work. Routledge

(Detailed references will be provided in the Course Outline of the respective academic year.)

courses.subject: SOWK
courses.title: Budgeting and Financial Planning in Social Service Organizations
courses.description: This course aims at helping students to understand the concepts, systems, and processes of budgeting and financial management in social service organizations within the local context and in mainland China. The course examines the nature and functions of budgeting and financial management in social service organizations, the similarities and differences of budgeting and financial management between for-profit and nonprofit organizations, the basic knowledge regarding budgeting and financial management in areas such as resource acquisition, distribution, control, recording, and reporting, the basic skills in budgeting and financial management including designing various forms of budgets, analyzing financial statements, raising funds, and writing grant proposals, and helps students gain an insight into recent trends and issues affecting budgeting and financial management for social service organizations and develop pertinent strategies to cater for these changes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
courses.course_syllabus:
- Challenges and Paradigm Shift in Philanthropic Development & Non-profit Financing
- New Public Financial Management of the Nonprofits
- Nonprofit-Business Collaboration: From Corporate Philanthropy, CSR to CSV
- Social Business and Social Impact Investment
- From Crowd-funding and Crowdsourcing to Sharing Economy for Non-profits
- Financial Planning and Budgeting Concepts and Techniques in Nonprofit Management
- Cost Accounting
- Capital Budgeting & Working Capital Management
- Project Grant-Making and Business Plan Formulation
- Financial Reporting and Analysis (1)
- Financial Reporting and Analysis (2)
- Performance Management, Internal Control and Public Accountability of Nonprofits
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation done by students, followed by discussions with students
2. Final evaluation by means of standard course questionnaire
courses.required_readings:
Bhandari, S.B. (2010). Ethical dilemma of nonprofits in the agency theory framework. Journal of Leadership, Accountability & Ethics, 8(2), 33-40

Finkler, S.A., Purtell R.M., Calabrese, T.D., & Smith, D.L. (2016). Financial management for public, health, and non-for-profit organizations (5th ed.). Upper Saddle River, N.J.: Prentice-Hall.
